150355896.review:
Furi, the game that convinced me that dodging bullets and parrying lasers is an essential life skill I never knew I needed. It's like a series of intense face-offs that make your typical office meetings feel like a walk in the park.

The graphics are so stylish, they make me want to take my sword and neon glow outfit to the next Zoom call. It's like the developers borrowed aesthetics from a cyberpunk fashion show and said, "Let's make it deadly."

The gameplay is a relentless dance of dodging, slashing, and trying not to scream when a boss's health bar refills for the umpteenth time. It's like a rhythmic ballet, but with more explosions and fewer tutus.

The story is a cryptic journey filled with enigmatic characters who speak in riddles, like a business meeting where everyone communicates in elaborate metaphors. You'll question everything, including why you're fighting a giant mechanical rabbit. Spoiler: Just go with it.

[h3]💬 Comments 💬[/h3]
[h2]Short Game Description[/h2] 
Furi is a boss rush game in which the story turns around the concept of "freedom" at the same time as we discover our old selves.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, first of all, the boss fights are great, with many varieties, making the whole experience exciting and challenging. Secondly, the parry mechanic was fair and very enjoyable. Plus, the long range was well implemented. Thirdly, most of the bosses were challenging and unique, as they required you to play in a certain way to be able to beat them. Additionally, the setting and the storytelling made the experience intriguing.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, the walking scenes sometimes last too long while not being that special. Besides, the dash mechanic is horrid, feels very bad when using it, and makes all the gameplay unresponsive. The reason is that the developers decided to activate the dash when you release the key, which in practice feels very bad. Also, the DLC doesn't add that much content; it would have been better if they added a few more bosses.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
In short, the gameplay is great, especially the parry mechanic that is well implemented with so many different unique bosses that they force you to play in a certain way to ensure that you are not just utilising the same mechanic over and over. Too, the story telling was intriguing, revolving around the freedom concept. Sadly, the dash mechanics were poorly implemented, and the DLC could have been better. The game is a 7.25/10.

148801725.review:
[h1]Furi: Short, but very, very sweet.[/h1]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
The age-old axiom of “size doesn’t matter, it’s what you do with it” couldn’t be more true with Furi. This game hardly lasts more than an evening, yet it has been permanently lodged in my memory for years now. A seamless combination of banging tunes and tight gameplay over an awesome boss rush will have you killing the same 10 enemies over and over again without ever getting bored. If you’re even remotely interested in Furi, I implore you to grab the nearest credit card and buy it. You’ll thank me later. 

[hr][/hr]

[b]Review:[/b]
I Actually finished with Furi a very long time ago now, and have been sitting on this for ages since. Ever since my first clear of this game I’ve known it deserved a perfect score, and even after putting the blood, sweat, and tears into the 100% run, I’ve struggled to find a single thing wrong with the game. The reason then that this review has taken years was not that I couldn’t decide how I felt about Furi, it was simply that I couldn’t figure out how to describe how good it is. 

[b]The size of your Furi doesn’t matter.[/b]

Video games in the last decade or so, especially the AAA side of the industry, struggle with a scope problem. Games are always trying to be the “biggest”, “longest”, “most innovative”. In a society where we are time strapped as is, it’s always amazed me that marketing a game to have over 100 hours of playtime is seen as a valid strategy. Even some of the best games in the last 5 years even have this issue (cf. Elden ring, a near perfect game that was just too long). Furi, however, does not. 
If you didn’t glean it from the store page, Furi is a boss rush. There are 10 boss fights, plus a couple of DLC fights, and that’s it. Every second of Furi’s time is accounted for, like the game went through an overly harsh edit over and over before finally releasing. I’m sure I don’t need to go into how much of a breath of fresh air this is. If you want to experience Furi, you’ll need to dedicate at most a couple of evenings to get the game over with, instead of removing yourself entirely from the outside world for a month. With how short, even compact it is, you can be sure that every second of Furi’s playtime has been accounted for, made use of in some way. The game even manages to tell a somewhat compelling and well thought out story, something the average 100-odd hour Ubisoft game struggles with. It might be initially surprising to you then that a large portion of Furi is simply just walking, walking that can be done automatically so that you can just set the controller down to watch and listen. These sections give the game space to slowly build up each boss fight, giving them the introduction they deserve, while the music works on introducing you to the next song on the legendary soundtrack. 

[b]Furiwave.[/b]

I normally try to avoid talking too much about the OST in my game reviews, the soundtrack of a game is massively important to me, but my knowledge of music rarely goes beyond “it’s good or bad”, only becoming important to my review if I feel like it drastically affects the game in some way. That said, I can’t talk about Furi without talking about this game’s soundtrack. Normally in a game, the gameplay takes priority over the music, and the latter is molded, bent to fit the former. Furi does this the opposite way. Sometimes this game feels like it was designed specifically around each track, almost as if it was just a clever interactive way for the artists to show off their songs. Those boss “buildups” I mentioned earlier? They introduce you to the boss, but more importantly they allow the soundtrack to slowly set the scene, allow it to build up and reach the biting point as you slip into each fight. I’ve never seen a game that manages to hype up each boss in such a way, while giving you a subconscious idea of what you’ll be expecting. It’s great. The music also changes mid-fight, flowing and changing from each phase to the next, mirroring the action perfectly. During my personal favorite boss fight, the high speed synthwave track slows to a slow grinding beat when you enter melee portions of the fights, while during another fight, a slow, dark, and simplistic track suddenly gains a powerful beat as the boss enters the “desperation” phase of the fight. Even if you’re skeptical about the bullet hell/parry gameplay style of Furi, if you like synthwave/electronic music, you NEED to play this game, just for the music. Luckily the game has some very well-tuned difficulty settings so that you can just enjoy the music and story without having to worry about the fighting if you choose.  


[b]Furier.[/b]

On the topic of difficulty settings, I wanted to talk about the hardest one. I’m sometimes a little skeptical of difficulty settings, as I think too many can often just undermine the quality of balancing (although I appreciate the accessibility, they provide to people without the time to git gud). Furi is one of those cases that proves difficulty settings can be amazing if done right. Furier, the highest difficulty in the game, is absolutely nuts. The bosses aren’t buffed in the classic sense, instead they’re almost entirely new bosses. The highest difficulty feels exactly like it should do – a much tougher challenge destined for those who’s mouths are watering for more Furi. I 100%ed this game, as I tend to do, and the run to complete Furier on S rank was a grueling, tiring one that took countless hours of practice. What it wasn’t, was frustrating. I’m sad that this game flew so under the radar as I think even juggernauts like Fromsoft have something to learn from how Furi handled it’s balancing. Furi is a game that gives back as much as you put into it, and the devs themselves understood this: As they put it: Furi is an instrument, and it was designed for players who practice it till mastery. 

I hope by reading this little love letter disguised as a review you decide to give it a go. There’s really little more I can do to sing this game’s praises other than buying the game for everyone who seems remotely interested, and I’m a little too broke for that. Furi won’t have you immersed for hours, but if you’re aching for a challenge, a new soundtrack to listen compulsively to, or a little of both, then this little hidden gem has you covered. Just remember, the Jailor is the key, kill him and you’ll be free.

148037076.review:
Good game overall, but it could've been one of the best indie games I've ever played if it wasn't for some issues that peeved me quite a lot.

[h1]+ PROs:[/h1]

+ Fast-paced combat and tight parry controls
+ Interesting setting and story
+ Cool character design and artistic direction
+ Kick-ass music

[h1]- CONs:[/h1]

- The dash control. No matter how you look at it, it sucks. It works on the release of the button, thus allowing it to be charged for greater dash distance, but 90% of times an instant, fast dash is required and there's just no time to remain still for a second or two while charging it- you can't even shoot while dash charging - therefore the player has to bear a constant half-second delay for the dash input to be executed. In a fast action game like this, this is an artificial difficulty barrier that makes fights more difficult than they should.
- The bullet hell sections are often plagued by a terrible camera perspective that makes extremely difficult to understand the distance between the player model and the incoming bullets/waves. This combined with the delayed dash creates very frustrating situations, that reach a peak of absolute vileness during the final battle against [spoiler]The Star[/spoiler].
- Perfect parries, which are supposed to be rewarding since they leave the enemy stunned and open for a flashy counter animation, are actually useless since said counter deals less damage then a regular sequence of normal slashes. Really stupid, if you ask me.

[h1]○ NEUTRAL:[/h1]

○ All the fights are basically structured in the same way: each boss has their unique attack pattern that the player has to figure out in order to understand when they are vulnerable, but there's always a first phase more focused on shooting and ranged attacks, where the player has to reduce the boss' "shield", followed by a phase where the characters are forced in melee battle and an actual life bar can be removed. Rinse and repeat until the final phase, which always involves a hard bullet hell section during which the boss is invulnerable and the player can do nothing but dodge the attacks until they stop and the boss is ready to be taken down with a finisher. Out of the 10 different boss battles, only a couple make the exception of being exclusively focused on melee and bullet hell fighting, respectively. Whether this particular game structure is good or bad is up to personal taste.

I strongly recommend to buy this game on sale while keeping in mind that the issues I've pointed out can be very annoying and frustrating, to the point of ruining the experience for some. I will also make a separate review once I'll have the chance to try the "Onnamusha" DLC that adds a new female counterpart of the protagonist, with a different moveset.

147973662.review:
A Neon Symphony of Swords and Struggle: Navigating the Visceral Challenge of FURI

🚀🤺 Furi: A Neon-Drenched Descent into Vengeance 🤺🚀

“I was nothing more than a weak rabbit, yet the path of vengeance molded me into a sword-wielding harbinger of freedom.”

In FURI, your journey is forged in the scorching crucibles of incredibly arduous battles, where your initial vulnerability morphs into a lethal precision, born from necessity and crafted through repeated, brutal failure. From the initial moment, when you, a prisoner, decide that freedom is worth any cost, the game throws you into a ravaging maelstrom of combat, where every misstep is ruthlessly punished, and every victory feels like a hard-earned triumph.

🔥 Unyielding Difficulties and Trials: The game’s remorseless difficulty is not merely a barrier but a meticulous teacher, forcing you to hone your skills, to understand each enemy, and to transform from a vulnerable captive into a relentless force. It's in this meticulously crafted difficulty where FURI transcends mere action, becoming a deeply personal journey of perseverance and evolution.

🗡️ The Path from Weakness to Power: The game begins with you as nothing, a captive with everything to gain and nothing to lose. Your journey from a “weak rabbit” to a being of potent vengeance is as much a narrative transformation as it is a mechanical one. Through each duel, your own skills sharpen alongside those of your avatar, turning every slash and shot into a visceral, satisfying impact.

🕵️ Veiled Narratives of Vengeance: Amidst the chaos of battle, the story unfolds like a shadowy tapestry of mystery and vengeance. The nuanced, concealed details of the plot are not mere context but are the heartbeat of your quest, driving every clash, every defeat, and every victory. The vagueness of your path only makes each revelation more potent, each discovered detail a precious shard of a deliberately obscured narrative mosaic.

🎵 Euphony of Combat and Soundtrack: As your blades clash and bullets fly, the kinetic soundtrack, featuring artists like Carpenter Brut and The Toxic Avenger, becomes a vital part of the experience. It is the pulsating rhythm to every encounter, a simultaneous manifestation of the aesthetic and the emotional journey within FURI, creating an indelibly immersive synergy of gameplay and music.

“My path was not merely an escape, but a relentless march towards retribution, crafted through the grueling anvil of each duel.”

In FURI, every defeat is a lesson, every victory a milestone, and your path from captive to avenger is a narrative wrought not just in the game’s story but in your own development as a player. It’s a challenging, enigmatic, and supremely satisfying odyssey through neon landscapes and formidable foes, where your evolution mirrors that of your avatar, transforming each clash into a personal and deeply satisfying tale of triumph.

🎮 Overall Rating: 9/10 🎮

🗝️ Here, in the vibrant shadows and intense battles of FURI, freedom is a journey through your own evolving skill, where the key is not merely victory, but mastery, understanding, and relentless perseverance. 🗝️

A decently entertaining and cryptic game. The game felt fairly difficult on the 2nd and last boss, otherwise most of the bosses felt like they posed a challenge but didn't really require a restart due to the game's tug-of-war mechanic.

Combat felt entertaining and very fast paced, and at times becomes very bullet-hellish. The bosses all had fairly unique gimmicks to them but all of the bosses revolve around destroying projectiles, dodging AOE/targeted waves, and parrying the boss's basic attacks.

I think the story can pique your interest, but leaves a bit to be desired as a lot doesn't really feel explained.

Overall, fairly fluid combat that poses a challenge and I think $20 is a fair price point for what the game offers in terms of content. There are other options it seems for a harder difficulty or alternate characters on game completion, but I didn't personally engage in these.

I enjoyed the majority of this game.
It wasn't anything crazy good or special, but it was overall fun.
However, this game did have a few central flaws to it.
1. The early game pacing did not leave me craving for more fighting after a fight and the 20 hour long walk after it, it made me wanna leave the game and come back **eventually**, which could well have been never. i almost quit the game halfway through because the pacing just left me not wanting to play. On the 2nd half of the game it got much better, the walks were shorter and the plot was more involved and left me wanting to play more.
2. The final boss of this game completely swapped out your mechanics. you still had dashes and guns, but that's it. Charged shot is completely different. No parrying to regen health. No melee attacks, You're much slower, etc. It didn't feel like a test of my skills, when i died it felt more like i wasn't prepared for this challenge properly than i just messed up. I didn't enjoy it at all. I finished it because i wanted to see the end, but i hated every second of that boss. It was honestly the only straight up unfun part of the game.
Overall this game was good, I'd give it a 7-8/10. Wait for a sale, it's not worth the full price.

Absolutely amazing game, one of my favourites of all time. From the soundtrack and narration to the gameplay itself, you can see how much love the creators of this product put into it. The backlog game of all backlog games!
Does it have banger music YES
Does it have a interesting story KINDA
Does it have a good artstyle or grafics MEH
Does it have good gameplay MEH
6-10 if you dont wanna read the rest

The game does alot of things right but a whole lot makes you dissapointed in the missed opertunties!

Let me start of with the music, I love the overall feel of the tracks and believe it deserves every praise but i wish there was more music in the game 
but presentation audio vice its pretty much perfect in my opinion!

I really enjoyed the story of loss and fighting to free yourself of your cage, fighting for what is right.
With that in mind i still believe it should have been changed in some way or another to make it less linear. It kind of just starts and ends with no real twist, turn and or question. This can be really good, dont get me wrong, but it wasnt just my cup of tea, and i believe it could have been better with a bit more time put into it!

I did enjoy the diffrent "boss arenas" but i still believe a bit more time could have been put to great use to make the enviorments larger and more expanded to give the world a bit more lore and intresting designs and i also felt like alot of the textures were either really simple or downright missing like i know its a artstyle choice but it felt to simple and beta like, it didnt feel like the one designing the artystyle had any real passion for the project. With this said i have to say its alot better then what halo infinte did with its "unreal 4" feel with lacking explosions and craig!
I just personally believe a bit more should have been placed in makeing the areans change, with the degredation of the bosses. 
Maybe have some sort of "easter egg" where you can be in awe of the design, with this said i thought the walking segments were pretty enjoyable change of pace and did somewhat give me a bit of what i wanted i just think a bit more time in those segments or segments filling their purpoes would be intresting, like a DMC minion arena or something like that (Im a DMC3 lover i know sorry!)

The boss design, there are good bosses, poor and just stupid
Most bosses of the game lack story or lore which makes the fights lack incentive on your part, most of the bosses boil down to you killed xyz and now im mad, there are good bosses dont get me wrong but they come in too late and or in my opinion lack the stuff that made bosses in DMC 3 or Metal gear revengence special. Like we do have a Samuel/Vergil fight but he isnt a reacuring caracter which made those so iconic they lack charm overall. With that said they did have some really good bosses. (sors for spoils)
 
Beating bosses dont earn anything after the fight. I know that every single boss doesnt need to drop a new mechanic, weapon and or thing for the game to still be intresting but compair this to the DMC series. In DMC every single boss leave a new mechanic for the player to explore after the fight which in turn increases the mechanical skill celing and gives the player a chance to make their own style. If we compair it to something like "Enter the Gungeon" which is also a bullet hell they even give alot more tools for the player to explore which in turn makes the combat more varied and intresting!
As of now you have access to a dodge, parry, gun, and sword and their charged versions but it really just boils down to spamm with no thought what so ever, and or a slog of trial and error without the good stuff that souls likes bring!

Overall a critical review but i was underwelmed by the positive reviews and found the game to be overated. Was it good tho? Yeah. I would only recomend getting this game on sale and i hope a sequel gets made which can improved opon the faults of the orignal!

144687624.review:
[h1]Intense Anime Fighting[/h1]
[i]And I Ioved every single second holding my breath in this game[/i]


[u]Furi, a game where vengeance and fury lead us forward, serving justice to the jailers.[/u]
[b]Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be thrown right into the final battle from the get go?[/b]
Well the tutorial fight would be your answer. Every single fight feels like a final boss, each one requiring focus, studying, timing, trial and error to defeat. You may find yourself angry, overwhelmed, hopeless or even fascinated, with enough optimism; by the various and continuous challenges that appear infront of you. Perhaps even all of them, as if going through multiple phases, just like the battles you face.

[u][b]I highly insist you stay on the normal intended difficulty[/b][/u] even if you feel the urge to switch to easy because a certain boss is whapping your butt. You cannot change the difficulty back once it's on easy. So just hang in there and try to master the boss's attacks until you nail that bastard.

[b]But now, the real hero of this game is the music[/b], like gah damm it hits hard with the vibe and theme of this game. And once you beat the game you will hear that beautiful credits music in the menu from then on out; hearing it after booting the game up again just made me feel rejuvenated, made me want to tackle this beautiful game again, and again and again...

[u]Some in-game knowledge.[/u]
[b]- Some battles include healing orbs (green projectiles) which you will have to attack and pick up if you want to restore a tiny bit of health, some bosses do not provide these, instead you heal by successfully parrying an attack.
- You have 3 lives in each battle, defeating 1 phase of a boss will restore 1 life, and defeating a phase will also restore your current health to full. When you die, the current phase you were on will reset. Upon losing all 3 lives you lose the battle and must restart.
- Holding your dodge will further increase your teleportation range.
- Sometimes staying close and personal to the opponent is easier and safer than letting them perform their ranged attacks.
- A few exception of attacks cannot be parried, and must be dodged/avoided.
- You can increase your attack damage in close combat by charging your Right Click.
- Attacking projectiles is often easier than trying to dodge them.[/b]



[b]I'm ranking the battles from best to worst based on my enjoyment and experience:[/b]

1. Paddle guy (The Edge) - Hard at first but becomes pretty enjoyable when you learn it. It's purely close combat so if you like that you will love this fight.

2. Fish face (The Scale) - It was pretty unique and cool concept, the music choice could have been better but I still enjoyed this fight a lot, it requires you to really think about where you step.

3. Torturer (The Chain) - Classic one, definitely deserves a decent spot in the list. Now it's definitely one of the easiest fights, or well easiest to learn I'd say because of the simplicity it introduces. But as a beginner it felt awesome.

4. Prisoner with anger management issues (The Strap) - A little too dank with the character design. I really enjoyed the concept of walls and them getting destroyed as you fight it out in the arena, it adds this cat and mouse feel to the battle when you have to hide out if you're ever in a pinch.

5. Main protag Knight (The Hand) - The battle relies mostly on close combat, or well a lot actually, so if you weren't good at close combat before, this boss would surely put you in your place to make sure you learn. Personally I think the battle is too repetitive, but I guess it goes out of it's way to teach you the mastery of parrying in a pretty effective way.

6. Sniper girl (The Burst) - Definitely the hardest battle in general out of all the guardians, as its requiring insane focus and reaction time. It's basically just a copy paste of The Strap battle but extra annoyingness. The character choice and design is a very stereotypical and mainstream sniper chick, [i][strike]cough widowmaker cough cough[/strike][/i], which I just find a bit cringe and unfitting in this game. Could have put a little more effort into the character itself.

7. Nice woman (The Song) - Everything feels like a cluster and intentionally annoying, that and you always fall off the map trying to dodge the bullet hell. I just wanted it to be over.

8. "MVP" Girl (The Beat) - [spoiler] She is so easy that you will feel bad for beating her[/spoiler] but definitely better than the crap boss below. 

9. Old geezer (The Line) - The fight has too much stalling, it feels very slow and boring, every time I had to restart the battle I felt like I was wasting my time significantly, because the battle wasn't even interesting.


Rankings in terms of difficulty:
1. The Burst
2. The Song
3. The Hand
4. The Edge
5. The Scale
6. The Strap
7. The Line
8. The Chain
9. The Beat

Thank you for reading this review and have a nice day, peace!

144132366.review:
SPOILERS
Currently working on the game through Furier difficulty, but I have completed the game in Furi difficulty and overall it was an enjoyable experience. It definitely does have some things that hold it back, so I hope to give a comprehensive and realistic review of the game for anyone looking to pick it up. 
Pros
Spectacle - This game looks and sounds fantastic to play. While the model quality isn't hyper-realistic triple A gold, it gives the game a distinct style that sets it above. The characters are a diverse in their designs, ranging from revamped embodiments of classic tropes(eg The Hand, The Song), bizarre new looks(eg The Voice, The Scale) or literal horror movie monsters. Looking at you, Strap. 
Controls - Yep, this game is responsive and gives you just enough variation in your moveset as to not overwhelm you with options but also so that you can find new stuff as you progress. Interesting stuff like boost and charge dodging can actually come in handy a lot, but if you want to stick to shooting and slashing, you'll be successful.
Fights - Some fights are more focused on parries, some are focused on shooting and dodging, and some require you to think outside the box completely, there's something for everyone whether you're a fan of Touhou or Sekiro.
FINAL SPOILER WARNING 
Cons 
Story - Story? What story? This game does very little in terms of worldbuilding or character development, as your silent protagonist just sort of gets up one day and chooses violence. The Voice was so nebulous and confusing that I was fully expecting him to either be the actual Jailer or a figment of The Stranger's imagination, alla Ninja Ninja from Afro Samurai. He gives you a bit of exposition before each fight which does an alright job characterizing each boss but just creates more questions as to what his true relationship is with the Guardians. The jail in general is never explained, only that the Guardians built it somehow to contain miscellaneous threats to the Free World, led by The Architect(aka The Voice). The twist at the ending showing that the Stranger is actually a member of an alien race who prolong the survival of their species by assimilating other worlds, and he was part of the Rider program that scout out the planet's surface before he was captured. Huh? What? The only time this was ever foreshadowed was The Line's dying words to look up to the sky, and some vague lines from The Song.
Overworld - The levels before fighting each boss would have worked much better as skippable cutscenes. the rigid 8 point movement and the constantly changing camera angles make traversing them boring at best, and actively confusing at worst. If they were simply cutscenes that play out, it would solve the issue of getting through them and allow them even more freedom with the camera. Although I suppose not having your movement free would make the Voice's ramblings even more unbearable.
Difficulty - The difficulty ramp up in this game has no rhyme or reason. Some bosses increase in difficulty from their predecessors, as they should, but some are significantly easier than the ones coming before them. I was very let down with the low difficulty of the Hand, Edge, and Beat fights. The Beat is especially offensive, as she is supposed to be the last guardian of the prison. The Voice makes it clear that she's actually quite weak compared to the other guardians and simply wanted to be the final obstacle out of some naive hero complex, but in that case I think the fight should have played out with her trying to fight you at first before realizing she has no chance and running away until she can't anymore and you finish her in 1 hit. That would have actually gone to lengths to show that she's pitiful as a warrior but her control of the area and its technology is truly unmatched. If she had really been the final boss, that would have left a terrible taste in any gamer's mouth. I sure hope the actual final boss stuck the landing...
The Star - It really baffles me how the final boss of the game takes away your sword, limiting you to just shooting. The fight in general felt very frustrating and restricting, which is the opposite of how I was expecting it to play out after I recieved a spacesuit mech. The difficulty was very well executed, as it was a significant challenge to overcome, but overall this fight did very little to carry the feel and spirit of Furi into its ending. Additionally, if you chose to assimilate the planet, you will have your save file reset and be unable to fight this boss(the same for if you choose to stay with The Song, but that's much earlier in the game).

Overall, Furi is not a perfect game, but it is super enjoyable. Would I say it's worth the $20 price tag? Not really. Wait for a sale, or buy it on G2A for $6. With a lower cost, I'd say this short and sweet game is a fantastic and unique experience.

I bought this game because I heard lots of good things about it and really liked its soundtrack. I wanted a single-player game and thought that this would be a fun challenge. I played through the entire game twice, once on Furi difficulty and again on Furier difficulty. My first playthrough was blind, I used speedrunning footage as a guide on the second playthrough. I have no interest as of right now of playing again, although it might be fun to revisit as a speedrunning challenge down the line.

I really wanted to like this game, but I found it hard to do so. I agree with a lot of the other more detailed negative reviews you can find for this game - it has TONS of stuff that I really love, but there's just a bunch of small issues that hold it back in my opinion. The combat system is incredibly fleshed out yet incredibly one dimensional at the same time, and the boss rush format of the game is tightly focused on what this game lives and dies by: the combat.

The core gameplay for a majority of the fights revolves around switching between a ranged bullet-hell type gamemode that lets you switch between your gun and your sword and a CQC phase that locks you in with the boss and forces you to get close and personal with your melee. The two phases feel very distinct, and offer a good bit of gameplay variety. The melee elements in the ranged mode... exist, I guess, but my main complaint lies in the interactivity of most of the ranged fights in the game.

A lot of them end up feeling tedious, especially on Furier, and for a game that really leans into being a fast pace game about dueling that was really disappointing. There's a couple really bad offenders here - especially on a first time playthrough - and it just felt like wasted potential. I love this game's melee combat - when I can actually do it. Most of the time I'm running around hoops trying not to get tagged by some orb or power wave and fighting my dashes. Again, this is really my fault for playing on MnK, but dashing on KB feels kinda awkward, especially in CQC phases. I understand that the game was designed around having a controller, but having the need for incredibly precise analog dashes is annoying and the workaround using the mouse to set direction in CQC feels really bad. I found myself just interrupting sweeping attacks instead of trying to dodge them since the odds of me just going in an unintended direction felt too high. Dodging via reticle can also be a chore, and the option to toggle between that and dodging based on movement was in a really unintuitive spot in the menus, so I didn't find it til like fight 8 of playthrough 2.

Like others before me have also noted, the risk-reward for using melee in ranged modes also feels... off, somehow. Even when you land parries, it just tends to be better to keep holding shots throughout the entire fight instead of trying to challenge bosses head-on with your sword. The game really doesn't like it when you try to hit people when you're not supposed to in both modes of combat, which feels really bad to me? I understand wanting to avoid letting people just mash attacks through a fight, but I wish this was played better, especially in the ranged fights. Maybe buffing the sword's effectiveness and changing the AI to favor melee attacks slightly more when mixing up their attack patterns would be enough, but as it stands, I really dislike how a lot of the combat feels.

HOWEVER, CQC feels ****ing phenomenal. Inputs are super tight, there's a notable push and pull between you and the boss, risk reward for options like powering up your sword is tangible, and dashing around to dodge attacks would feel great (MnK problem, YMMV on controller). You could make the argument that it's really just a rhythm game in disguise (doesn't help that the game gives a super noticeable "PRESS F NOW!" prompt that makes parrying a lot easier for most bosses) but it never felt like that in a fight. It felt like I was trading blows with formidable opponents, learning how they fought and slowly overcoming them. I wish the whole game felt that tight throughout - it would have alleviated a lot of the frustration. Ranged mode feels like the homework I have to get through in order to play these incredible segments of gaming.

I think the most honest way I can describe this is that the elation of beating a boss was not a "I did it" feeling but more of a "Thank God I don't have to do this again," which is not a good sign for a game that is centered around running the same boss rush over and over again. I wanted to give this game a fair shake, so I replayed it on Furier, but I'm not sure if I feel like that's time well spent. I guess I could spend time going through and S-Ranking the game, and yeah, maybe I'd get more of an appreciation for the game's mechanics and learn to love the bosses I don't like, but I would rather spend my time doing other things, playing other games.

When it comes to presentation, there's things that I like and things that I don't. This game has a nutty OST (it's how I found the game, I'm a sucker for anything with Carpenter Brut on the side) which is easily worth the listen, even if you never plan on playing the games. The graphics are... fine, I suppose. They're stylized in a way that alleviates the things I don't like partially, but the weak out-of-fight animations don't really do much for me. I think some more expressive animation on The Voice and less clipping and stilted feeling animation on the main character would have done wonders for my enjoyment of the game. That being said, the art for the game is really nice. The character designs are all interesting, the levels themselves are really cool conceptually, I like the kind of surreal feel of all the different worlds, so on that front, this game is a success. 

PROS:
+ Strong OST
+ Melee Fighting feels wonderful
+ Game is very tightly focused on what it wants to do, which I can respect
+ Good Art Direction
+ Satisfying to complete
+ No artificial difficulty
+ I hear thunder (pitterpatter)
+ Fights are beautifully animated

CONS:
- Game sometimes doesn't let you play the fun bits
- Game doesn't let you play the fun bits a lot, actually
- Game took the fun bits out of some of the fights :(
- Animation is wack outside of fights
- Controls on MnK are very unrefined

I really wanted to like this game - and it was so, so close to being a really fun game. Despite that, the combat is bogged down by its unfun segments so I don't want to replay the game, and the game is so short and so small that I don't feel like I got my money's worth out of this game and wouldn't unless I really wanted to grind out better ranks. 

This game feels like it was mostly a bullet hell, so keep that in mind.

142776519.review:
Furi is a tough as nails boss rush title that has you facing off against 12 jailers standing between you and freedom. The game has one of the best EDM soundtracks you'll find and some very stylish battles done in full anime chique with some brutal combat animations.

Fights go down in roughly 3 different segments. Firstly you have some freedom to move around as the boss pursues you. Then there are the close up sections where you're forced into tight quarters with the boss. Then there are the bullet hell segments where the boss unleashes a lengthy volley of attacks at you which you need to learn to navigate using your gun and dashes to carve a path.

Every fight has it's own unique gimmicks and challenges - they become as much puzzles as fights in that sense. The difficulty is punishing though it is possible to recover some health through perfect performance. The fights are long and arduous requiring you to memorize different patterns and make use of very sharp reflexes, so it can get very challenging quickly.

While I love watching the game be played it's stressful to experience first hand and by the time I got to the 4th boss some of the patterns can get real wild, requiring twitch reflexes and perfect inputs otherwise you get badly punished and have to restart long sections over again. Personally I wasn't into that sort of repetition and called it quits - considering how intense the game gets later on I'm not mad that I did.

High points for sheer style and presentation, the gameplay is fun and intense but probably best suits a more resilient and persistent player, unfortunately that isn't me.

-Only like 4 hours to beat

-Extremely long unskippable cutscenes which are literally just slow walking and cliche babble from some dude who you never learn anything about. 
-the dash, i.e your entire means of dodging a great deal of attacks, is extremely inconsistent

Attack choreographing/clarity is clearly an afterthought. Boss animations will be reused for entirely different attacks, cannot describe how crap that is. Whether or not you can hit something is entirely a "true/false", and whether or not a parry will allow you to attack or do nothing at all to them is largely arbitrary; you have to try it to find out and memorize that

This game made me feel trapped. It's like getting challenged to a fight by a fat kid in the park: if you say no, you're a pussy, but the fight is crap, and not really that hard other than the fact that his buddy keeps kicking you in the nuts.

It mistakes lazy story-telling for "mysterious" and barely functional player mechanics for "challenging". 

It just feels underdeveloped at every turn, like the environment artist was meant to carry the whole game:
The Song will repeat her voice lines every 10 seconds in the cutscene before the fight as though it's a game from 2005. Bosses can be made to run from you infinitely just by standing next to them when the developer expects you not to. Hell, the character's feet clip through the floor as he walks through every cutscene where the main focus is, guess what, *walking*. They didn't even bother to make a real cursor for the KBM controls.

That'd all be fine if you're just trying to get a functional game out quick because I know most game dev projects never pan out in the end, but seriously if you have only a small handful of mechanics, make SURE you got those right.. Otherwise the whole game stinks of either low, budget, low time, or low effort.

Note that this review is based on the first two hours of gameplay 
Why? Because I was so bored in the first two hours that I decided to refund the game on steam.

The game just plays like a really long quick time event. As other negative reviews have mentioned, fights are scripted. You're only allowed to damage the boss at certain times. Either the boss will just have an incredibly long invulnerability phase while you wait for them to get over their temper tantrum, or they'll just dash away immediately until it's the correct "time" in the script. 

The game was hyped to me by a friend years ago. It's been on my wishlist since and I've been binging all those games in my backlog. Maybe it has something to do with the fact that I've played many amazing games in the last month as part of this cleanup process, but Furi does not fit in that category.

Gameplay feels unrewarding and boring. It's a boss rush only kind of game, so there are no little minions on the path to each area. And the "bosses" are boring and unrewarding. Instead you have this terribly slow walking transition between each boss with boring commentary that doesn't add to the atmosphere at all. Finishing a fight is unrewarding because the only thing after is more boring transitions. 

After an hour and a half and 6 bosses (according to online lists this is half the game) I was having no fun and decided to refund the game. Every boss is more or less the same thing and you're just sitting there holding whatever button they're asking you to hold during that section. Fights are slow paced and not impactful. 

I'm not sure why they lock away the "Furier" difficulty which might make things a bit more interesting. As it stands, the default "Furi" difficulty feels like a 4 hour tutorial just to unlock the rest of the game, something I wasn't willing to put up with. And even then, I'm not confident that the Furier difficulty would add anything meaningful to the game.

140835781.review:
Great boss rush (exclusively boss battles) game! Bosses are usually a mixture of bullet hell which demands precise dash-dodging and melee combat which demands well-timed parrying, with some bosses leaning heavily towards one aspect or the other. The game is pretty fast-paced and manages to be difficult despite having simple controls. The difficulty can be frustrating, but it also makes the the moment you defeat a boss all the more satisfying! Once you beat a boss in story mode, you can replay it anytime in practice mode under any unlocked difficulty.

The default difficulty mode is Furi (normal). Once you beat the story on Furi, you unlock Furier (hard) mode, which is supposedly the 'intended' difficulty of the game. There is also a Promenade (easy) mode where the boss fights are significantly easier and shorter (from what I've heard as I've never tried it), but that mode doesn't unlock anything and is intended solely as a way for players to experience the story without having to grind through difficult boss battles.

All I've done so far is beat the story once on Furi mode, which unlocked Furier mode as a result. I won't be attempting Furier anytime soon as I need a break because the game is pretty intense and I'm not really a hardcore gamer, but I gotta say beating it on Furi mode itself was a unique and worthwhile experience.

140201314.review:
Furi is so close to being amazing, but it slips up on the most crucial step to making it there. (To note, I played this game on Furier mode my first time through, as I wanted both the developer's intended experience, and I love a good challenge.)

Furi has some of the best, most engaging and challenging bosses I've seen in an action game. Each boss carries their own personal flavor and style, tackling different parts of the games mechanics and combining uses of them together in continuously interesting ways. Even in the fights themselves, there's constant variation going on, such as constantly changing and evolving attacks or unique arenas, while still keeping true to and expanding upon the bosses core theme and mechanical focus. I think it'll be a long time until I see an action game with bosses this good. That makes it all the more disappointing to say that this game is taken down by a health system that's far too forgiving. Leniency and making things easier not inherently bad, but the way they implement it is what does it in. 

Think about how Dark Souls handles health and healing. Every fight, you only have a very limited amount of health. The only way to gain it back is via health vials, which gives back a limited amount of healing and stops you dead in your tracks. This creates a risk reward system to using vials, while also adding an extra layer of strategy. When is it safe to use it? Should I wait to take a bit more damage so I get to use this vial to it's fullest potential? Should I heal now that a phase change is coming up I've never done? Etc. This is constantly going through your mind each step in battle in Dark Souls. The vials make a system that creates strategy, resource management, and forced mastery of every boss. You have to learn all the bosses by memory to get past them, which helps lift up its admittedly repetitive boss design.

Now, compare to Furi. You start every fight with 3 lives. Every life lost fully heals both you and the boss, but the boss stays on the current phase they're on. Every phase beaten will replenish your health and give you an extra life back. Parrying also grants you some bonus health. See the issue? When the game gives you health (which you could theoretically heal infinite of) and lives, it creates gameplay that focuses not on mastering the bosses, but on getting to the final phase at the same state you were in at the beginning. You can die on each phase in this game but suffer zero actual punishment by the final phase. This sadly undermined most of the combat in the game for me, and turned bosses into just getting past the fluff to get to the real challenge. The fix is so easy too, it could literally be made in a patch.

I can't hate Furi on the whole because, even despite the major flaw, pretty much everything else is perfect. I mentioned the boss design before, but the music, story, visuals, writing.. all of it is really fucking good. I could never not recommend the game because of just how good those aspects are. And at the end of the day, I still had fun. I just wish it could've made that final step.

139446077.review:
Furi is a video game that meticulously weaves together elements of bullet-hell shooters and reflex-intensive melee combat into a vivid tapestry of adrenaline-pumping action. The game dares to blend two distinct play styles and, in doing so, manages to redefine both in an exciting, fresh manner.

The soundtrack is an absolute standout. In fact, to merely say I "loved" it would be an understatement. The music engulfs the player, creating an intense ambiance that harmoniously syncs with the fast-paced action unfolding on the screen. It amplifies every moment, transforming each encounter into a fever-dream of lights, colors, and beats. The score is nothing short of an audio masterpiece that resonates long after you've put down the controller.

"Furi" is not a game that compromises on difficulty. It is genuinely challenging, even on the most basic level. The game continually pushes you, requiring a blend of strategy, fast reflexes, and perseverance. But rather than feeling unfair, the challenge is invigorating. It instills a deep sense of accomplishment with every victory, a testament to the well-designed gameplay mechanics.

All things considered, "Furi" is a marvel, seamlessly combining seemingly disparate game mechanics into a coherent, thrilling experience. Its top-notch soundtrack and demanding difficulty curve make it an unforgettable journey for those who dare to engage. Undoubtedly, "Furi" is a treat for both bullet-hell enthusiasts and melee-combat lovers alike, a testament to innovative game design and a benchmark for future titles in this genre.

Vive la France, merci à toute l'équipe, les programmeurs, les infographises, les musiciens !

[h1]What do we fight for ?[/h1]
Is the main question Furi ask to the world.

[b]On my first playthrough, I fought out of curiosity[/b]. 
Ignored the warnings, out of anger, sorrow, pride, despair, challenge, anger, and finally joy. These are all the emotions I went through as I played this game. 
And yet, you become the worst version of yourself, which happens to also be the best.

[i]"What would you do if had an eternity to do nothing but wait? Do you keep busy, do you daydream, do you freak out? He trained."[/i] - The Voice [spoiler] mentionning the Edge[/spoiler]


It's confusing how this game is [u]a hell of a trip[/u], as it is relatively [b]poor visually[/b], but yet so [b]rich in mechanics[/b], and so [b]deep in meanings[/b].

It can crack your soul open, as you keep trying, and trying. As the music infiltrate your skin to make you feel the battle that's going on your screen as well as in your mind. Keep trying, until you vanquish and master, the obstacles of your way.

[i]"Excellence isn't an art, it's a habit. We are what we repeatedly do."[/i] - [spoiler]The Edge[/spoiler]


[b]Furi is a challenge, as well as a lesson.[/b]

I will never master it, as I will never be the best version of myself.

[h2]Yet, as long as I breath, I'll keep giving it a shot.[/h2]

137703299.review:
[i]Furi[/i] is a game that I really wanted to like.  It pulls heavily from a lot of my favorite works, most prominently the general soundscape/vaporwave aesthetic of Dennaton's [i]Hotline Miami[/i] with a heavy dose of Takashi Okazaki's [i]Afro Samurai[/i] to taste (the main character of [i]Furi[/i], the Stranger, is pretty shamelessly cribbed from the character design for titular character Afro, and his sidekick The Voice is an equally-obvious composite of the characters Ninja Ninja and Kuma with just a little bit of [i]Donnie Darko[/i]'s Frank).

However, on the surface it looks like it'd be a character action brawler in the vein of [i]Afro Samurai[/i]'s own video game outing, and it's really not that at all.  What it is, primarily, is a bullet hell game.

Each stage of the game features a looooong stretch of expository dialogue, followed by a showdown with a boss character who has some new arrangement of flying projectiles to dodge.  Once you've learned the patterns to dodge each attack, plinking away with an [i]Ikaruga[/i]-esque handgun, you get a fleeting chance to close the distance and do a timed melee sequence that's not unlike a quicktime event to knock the boss' health bar down, before the boss resets its health bar and the pattern repeats, sometimes going faster or adding additional phases/mechanics.  It's a gameplay loop that demands patience and trial and error, working your way up through several mistimed prompts and bad dodges until you finally get the perfectly-timed combo that allows you to progress to the next stage.

This is fine, but it didn't really cater to the badass samurai feeling I wanted from the title; handling the Stranger really feels more like flying a spaceship through an asteroid field than it does like controlling a samurai duelist.

Consider this review a thumbs-up if you're really into [i]Touhou[/i], [i]Jamestown,[/i] [i]Danmaku[/i], and the like, but learning patterns by rote to mimic the perfect timing of button inputs just wasn't quite what I wanted from a title selling this kind of fantasy.  From a technical and artistic perspective, everything is super cool, but it just wasn't the kind of game that I was told it would be like.  Bullet hell games aren't really my jam, and it doesn't have the endless replayability for me that it seems to have for other people.  Once I felt I'd 'solved' each boss battle, that was the end of my engagement with it.

At only a few hours long, it's also a pretty steep ask for $20, but maybe it'll vibe with you better than it did with me.

136596804.review:
Furí– Cuando la rabia se apodera de ti en un Boss Rush

Furí, es un juego que salio de manera exclusiva y temporal en la playstation 4 al poco de sacar Sony el servicio de Playstation + allá por el julio de 2015 esta publicado y desarrollado por “The Game Bakers” los mismos creadores del videojuego Haven, os dejo una tarjetita en la esquina porque literal fue el juego que me pase antes de este y tiene su análisis respectivo, así que denle amor y compasiones.

Furí diría que fue uno de los juegos que no es que definieran, pero si que de alguna manera pusiera de moda tanto el genero, Boss Rush como también que la gente se pase un juego en el menor tiempo posible, o lo que hoy se conoce como Speed Run. 

Historia

Haber la verdad es que la historia es simple, tu tienes que huir de una cárcel, que esta en medio del espacio para ser libre al mundo humano normal y corriente, tu eres un samurái que tienes una katana y una pistola que esta encarcelado y quiere huir, has muerto mas de 2000 veces y estas jarto y quieres huir de hay. Entre combate y combate hablara un personaje contigo, no sabes quien es pero es ahí, aunque al cabo de un tiempo empiezas a percibir quien, o por lo menos me paso a mi.

Combate

Haber el combate a grosso modo, es usar una pistola y una katana como veréis, cada enemigo tiene una barra de vida pero debajo de esa barra hay unos cuadritos, pues esos cuadritos, son las barras de vida de ese enemigo, al igual que las tuyas, solo que las tuyas siempre serán tres ¿entonces cual es el objetivo y la dificultad al mismo tiempo?

Cada vez que tu le quites una vida a cada enemigo, el combate se complica, porque cada vez acabas con una barra de su vida, tendrá unas nueva mecánica y tendrás que descubrir como hacerle frente con lo que tienes a tu disposición, porque no hay ataques especiales, no hay perks con los que te puedas equipar, diría que tus únicas habilidades, son el ensayo + fallo y error + el parry  !!o amado parry¡¡ te alabamos gloria al parry. 

Porque alabo al parry, porque cuando lo ejecutas adecuadamente te da fragmentos de vida, vamos que si o si tienes que hacerle frente al enemigo aunque hay otra forma de obtener algo de vida y es que depende del enemigo puede que te dispararen de tal manera que tu piensas que no juegas a Furi, si no al Space Invader de la Atari, porque disparan a veces orbes, que dependiendo de su forma, podrás romper, bloquear o devolvérselo al enemigo de turno, la cosa es que entre esos orbes están los verdes, esos, son lo que te dan vida. 

Por lo tanto te puedes alejar, para ver si dispara algo, porque claro, cada enemigo porta armas diferentes, desde una espada, una francotiradora y hasta uno que usa el agua para emborronar la pantalla y que no puedas observar bien que sucede. Algo que puede dificultar mas los combates es que cuando tu le quitas toda esa barra de vida que tu crees que ya todo a acabado y no queda otra debajo, y te queda una parte fundamental de los combates, los duelos, porque al tu quitarle toda esa primera capa de vida el enemigo se aturde, pero al atacarle entras en ese modo duelo sobre todo no en los primeros compases si no casi al final de estos y cuando ya ye acuerdas de la descendencia de los creadores de Furi, es cuando queda solo una barra y el enemigo se vuelve tan loco, pero tanto que no hay ataque que cubra la pantalla. 

Diversidades funcionales

Haber no se como empezar este bloque, porque una de las cosas peores y mas obvias pero a la vez mejores que tiene furí, son los pingasos que te vas a comer, si Youtube, desmonetizame, pero es que real que te vas a comer ostias gratis, encima es que hay dos logros que se basan en las veces que perderás y tendrás que volver a intentarlo, te hartaras y dirás, ¡bueno, hasta mañana! cierro el melón de la rabia por hoy, lo sé, porque ma’pasao.

Respecto a las diversidades funcionales, por lo menos en mi caso, son los destellos, claro, cada vez que tu tengas que hacer un parry, veras un mini destello en los enemigos, no se si a bote pronto, que no veas bien puede que sea un poco difícil de detectar, porque, pues porque cuando hagan una sucesión de ataques, tu como buena funcionaria de los Guitar Hero, te terminaras dando cuenta que en esa sucesión de ataques, siempre, pero casi siempre hay uno, que te rompe el ritmo, por lo tanto, comerás pene, te gustara, no, pero es lo que hay si quieres un reto. Te recuerdo que también tienes otro reto mas grande que Furi y es tu vida, si te la estas pasando, intentalo con Furi.

Pero te tengo una buena y una mala noticia amige, el juego tiene un modo invencible, yo no lo use, yo fui a pelo, no cambie nada del mando ni mapeé los botones del mando tampoco, que te da ese modo, pues la capacidad de centrarte en la historia y una serie de comandos que te ayudan en los combates, también hay un modo practica, que te ayudan en los combates y un apartado de como se juega, no lo use, porque con el principio y las tres pinceladas del tutorial lo pille, pero cada enemigo es diferente eso si.


Música 

En su momento la banda sonora de este juego fue muy alabada, porque esta compuesta por Danger, quien ya colaboro con ellos en Haven, banda sonora compuesta por el directamente y también esta  Lorn, entre otras personas de la escena indie del mundo de la música electrónica, date una vueltita por su banda sonora, porque lo merece.

Conclusiones

El juego me ha durado unas 8 horas, es rejugable, eso nadie se lo quita porque tiene un modo de dificultad mas elevado, pero como en Grindr, next. El juego cuesta 20€ y escuchame, que los vale, Furí tiene dos DLC, llamados One More Fight y Onnamusha, el primero como bien dice, una pelea mas, y el otro, es otro personaje, que tiene diferentes variantes de combate, la verdad es que esto yo lo pille en oferta, están muy chachis, igual mas adelante me lo paso con esta otra personaje, ya os dire, que igual por la plataforma morada. Uff, que casi se me va la flapa, el juego esta en todas las plataformas.

Espero que os guste mi contenido, os suscribáis, lo compartáis con otras personas y nos vemos en el próximo video maripino.

136541468.review:
[h1]a boss rush game done right[/h1]

so basically this is how each fight works : the boss will go through several phases and within each phase there are two sections of battle, one that utilizes the entire arena dodging bullets or whatever they throw at you and another that is a close melee section, you have three lives and if you die you have to start that phase from the beginning and if you lose all three of your lives you'll have to do the battle all over again from the start, and also you get a life back for every stage you beat, sounds simple, right? well the general idea is simple, but the battles are FREAKING HARD AND I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT.

you can attack with your sword and your gun which both can be charged up for higher damage and for defense you can dodge or parry, but let me tell something, just learn parrying bro, you'll get the hang of it after like 5 minutes, trust me there will be bosses that you can only parry their attacks, you can't run away all the time (also you regain a little bit of hp after a successful parry). the parry mechanic is where this game truly shines, there is just something so satisfying about parrying in this game, if you time the parry closer to when you would get hit it initiates a cutscene which not only looks and feels cool to pull off but it gives extra damage to the boss, each boss is a huge challenge that feels amazing when you overcome it and none of the bosses are similar to each other, you'll have to master all of your abilities in order to defeat the bosses and finish the game, some bosses are purely melee focused while some other ones literally fly off to freaking nowhere and you must shoot them.

when you finish the game once it unlocks the furier mode and unlike most other hard modes in games, all the bosses now have completely different and much harder attack patterns than before. you're gonna have to relearn how to take each down in new ways, also they have a speedrun mode which is a blessing (seriously though, why can't all games have a dedicated speedrun mode?! ) 

other than the gameplay there are a tons of more great things about this game, like the aesthetic and graphics, the cutscenes you get after defeating each boss, even better the soundtrack, OMFG I LOVE THE SOUNDTRACK, it's definitely one of the best OSTs in the video game industry, also it has a japanese VA which is amazing, they hired better voice actors than most of the AAA companies do, and about the story, while it might look simple at first, trust me, there is a lore and meaning behind it ...

couldn't ask for a better game, thank you Game Bakers for this amazing masterpiece.

136460668.review:
Un indie soulslike que si bien no destaca en nada, hará las delicias de los jugadores que quieran un reto directo. Pasa por los mundos cárceles y mata al carcelero cueste lo que cueste. ¿Libertad o redención?. Dentro reseña!

Otro más pasado en Steamdeck y es que nos encontramos ante un juego con mecánicas soulslike y una vista cenital. Somos alguien que quiere escapar de su cárcel y para ello deberá matar a todos los carceleros hasta conseguir la "libertad".

El protagonista, que no habla, porta una especie de katana espada y una pistola. El moveset, aunque corto, es directo y suficiente, con un dash (que se puede mantener pulsado para alcanzar distancia), un parry para bloquear destellos blancos, con el joystick dispararemos o dejaremos cargado el arma y poco más. En esencia es un boss rush donde cada boss tiene unas mecánicas diferentes en mundos diferentes. Cuando pasamos entre boss y boss será un sendero para andar donde una especie de conejo loco (a lo Alice) nos contará más sobre nosotros y sobre el mundo de los carceleros. Y ahí se basa en toda la historia. Voces en inglés o japonés y texto en castellano. La historia, aunque justa, es suficiente para querer saber más de este mundo. Pero donde reside la gracia es en el gameplay y la dificultad.

Antes de entrar al tema, tenemos 3 dificultades, paseo (a la que tuve que cambiar a mitad del juego) donde los bosses tienen menos vida y te quitan menos, normal y difícil que se desbloquea al pasar. Además tenemos ranking mundial imagino de tiempo a modo de "online". También contamos con un modo invencible para aquellos que solo quieran saber de la historia. Es decir, de alguna manera es adaptado a cualquier público. El normal me pareció muy difícil al cuarto boss (habrá como 9-10) y aún en paseo, alguno me costó. Si te gustan los soulslike y los juegos difíciles entonces prueba en normal o siguiente, si lo tienes y quieres saber la historia, pues prueba en paseo y si no el modo invencible. Cada pieza de música cambia según el boss.

Y ahora vamos a las mecánicas. Tu tienes un número de barras de vida. Y el boss igual (va aumentando según avanzas). Y consiste en llegar a 0 cada barrita antes de que la tuya lo haga. Si uno de los dos llega a 0, el otro tendrá toda su barra llena y el que haya perdido tendrá un slot menos de vida. Y para ello tendremos que adaptarnos (no al escenario, pues son "arenas" circulares al uso) si no a las mecánicas. Todos tienen varias fases así como los famosos bosses de fromsoftware, atacar a distancia, bloquear parrys seguidos o esquivar.

Si bien todo es en vista cenital, y esto no me gusta en exceso, se hace muy entretenido y un reto a batir. Cuando le quitas una vida, tendrás que quitarle la misma vida pero en un modo "tercera persona", cámara al hombro, golpear, esquivar y atacar. Cuando bloqueas o en otras situaciones encontramos "finishes" o algún QTE como mover rápido los joysticks para librarnos de un ataque. Al pasear entre boss y boss no podremos interactuar con nada.

En cuanto a rejugabilidad, bueno puedes mejorar tu puntuación, probar una dificultad extra, algún personaje de pago con otro moveset y poco más. Si te gustan los retos, un boss rush siempre entra bien. Tiene un modo práctica también. En definitiva, encontramos un batiburrillo de cosas que si bien no se hace pesado, no destaca en nada. A veces parece un street fighter, otras una fase de Nier Automata, en otras una novela visual con fondo y en otras un juego hack and slash o de acción. 

Me gustaría otro juego del mismo mundo, explicando más del lore, que sea más largo (este puede durar 3-5 horas dependiendo de la dificultad la primera run), con un gameplay más definido y no tan generalizado, con un mundo abierto y con los mismos gráficos que si bien a día de hoy van justos, es colorido, así como viñetas, dándole un toque personal y atractivo. Lo he jugado en 1080 60fps en steam deck y no ha habido ningún problema.

Y hasta aquí, probad Furi tanto si os gustan los retos como si buscáis una historia distópica y rara, o simplemente algo rápido para echar partidas cortas, porque FURI no os decepcionará. Encima debe estar barato de narices. Gracias por leer! <3

135367139.review:
You ever play table tennis against a wall to see how many hits in a row you can get? Getting 100 hits in a row isn't hard; but it takes forever. If you miss at 60 and have to restart, the next try is substantially less fun as you work back up to 60 again. Furi feels just like that. It tries to convince you its [i]'hardcore difficult'[/i], when in reality it's '[i]challenging-ish'[/i] and needlessly time consuming.

Even though I cleared most bosses in fewer than 5 attempts, Furi felt like a janky, monotonous time-sink that relied too heavily on artificial difficulty to drive the experience.  

I understand I'm in the minority, but I recommend skipping this title. If you are looking for examples of polished boss rush/bullet hell games that pull off what Furi couldn't, I'd recommend looking to Enter the Gungeon or Eldest Souls first.

----------- [b]More Details / Full Review [/b] -----------

After playing Furi, I reflected on all the positive reviews that influenced my decision to try the game. Many of these reviews touted Furi as one of their best/favorite games of[i] all time[/i]. Personally, I don't get it. I'm not trying to [i]trash[/i] the game. It's just that the game I read about, and the game I experienced seem [i]wildly[/i] [i]different[/i].

[b]----- Qualms with Difficulty -----[/b]

I have qualms with the difficulty, but [i]not[/i] because the game is 'too hard'. I love bullet hells & boss rushes, and completed Furi with very little trouble. It wasn't 'easy', but seeing credits roll didn't instill a feeling of accomplishment, either. Furi attempts to cater to two disparate player groups at the same time: those seeking a punishing, intense, skill-based crusade, and more casual players looking for a tough but [i]forgiving[/i] one. It feels like the game was afraid of isolating either player group, and so it didn't commit to one or the other. The whole experience felt so shallow as a result. Allow me to explain...

Even on the hardest difficulty, you'll recoup health + lives after finishing boss phases. Successful parries heal you, and health drops are everywhere. You can't die unless you fail the same boss phase twice in a row. I don't know why they wouldn't save [i]some[/i] of this for easy mode instead. I get the feeling that these health systems were retrofitted to accommodate how 'artificially difficult' the game is. The game is only 'frustrating' due to lame systems that increase the time it takes to move through phases of a fight.

[b]----- It just takes too long -----[/b]

Bosses have between 4 to 6 'phases' which are comprised of 2 health-bars each. A full combo will deliver at most 20% of a single health bar. Scripted animations for executions and parries take 3 to 4 seconds, and you aren't rewarded with extra damage for the effort. There are even more animations between each boss phase. Fights are scripted in such a way that if you swing at the boss before you are 'supposed to', they get magic invulnerability frames or the ability to teleport away instantly. Taking risks or trying to be creative in combat wont pay off, because it's a matter of 'go here, wait, and attack when you're allowed to attack'. Certain bosses will run off mid fight, forcing you to wait up to 10 seconds for them to return. New combat phases don't introduce anything new or exciting, which left me wondering what the point was in having 6 phases (12 health bars), if not only to extend the length of the fight.

All this to say that fights are so much longer than they need to be. Reaching your previous point of failure is tedious and punishing, but only because it takes so much time. This game loop doesn't test your skill. It somewhat tests your memory, but mostly tests your patience.

[b]----- Lack of Variety -----[/b]

I was let down with how 'samey' every boss felt to one another. In a game with 10+ bosses, I'd have hoped to get something different out of each boss... But outside of the environment and bullet hell sequences, the fights all boiled down to the same pattern / formula. As mentioned earlier, each of a boss's phases aren't different enough from one another to make new phases feel fresh and interesting. Again, it felt like they were too afraid of making meaningful changes that would subvert expectations of players who memorized attack patterns of the current phase. I wish they went full-send, and instead made each phase truly special and unique.

[b]----- Story -----[/b]

I wasn't interested in the story at all, but the game forced it on me via painful walking intermissions that I could not skip. I got so used to putting 'auto-walk' on, that my character went AFK at a certain point in the story, triggered a secret ending, and I had to start the whole thing over. This was a huge turn-off, and I almost put the game down right then and there.[list][/list][list][/list]After sleeping that frustration off, I decided to finish the game I paid for so I could progress in the story. There's not much for me to say on this front. The writers needed a reason for a guy to be fighting a ton of bosses, so they worked backwards from that and it serves its purpose well enough. The voice acting and script were well done, but the pacing, timing of character dialogue felt off to me. The story is just not why you'd play this game.

[b]----- Conclusion -----[/b]

I felt pretty blindsided and uncalibrated by all of the positive press that didn't match my experience. I understand I'm in the minority of reviewers and if your experience was better than mine, I think that's fantastic! I'm simply writing the review that would have prevented me from playing a game that I didn't end up enjoying.

Beat the game but it is actually one of the most insufferable and overhyped games I've had the displeasure of playing. You are basically forced to play the game first on baby mode which is mind rottingly boring and then you can get to the "fun" difficulty.
The "story" they force you through includes: 
A silent awkward main character
Annoying voice lines
3 minute long auto walking sections that change camera angles so often which skews the controls in such a way you might as well let the game do it for you instead of flicking your stick around like an inept monkey

Everyone keeps saying that the gameplay is great and the music is good but I feel like I'm playing a completely different game from them. The music has the same 3 second loop over and over and the gameplay well... 
 
The gameplay is occasionally fun. The melee attacks feel a little choppy at times but you can force yourself to be fast and have more fun. The only issue is the enemies will just auto parry or block your attacks with no indicator saying that they can or can't take damage. One boss in particular has a counter animation where if you win the QTE it does literally nothing. Basically removing an entire mechanic from the game because it does nothing but waste time.

The gun is one of the most boring things I had to interact with and the first playthrough boiled down to hold right stick in the general direction of the enemy and avoid slow moving projectiles.

If you want good melee combat with cool fluid movement play Metal Gear Rising or if you like challenging games play Sekiro. This just ain't it. I was genuinely bored playing this game and I play Destiny 2 for God's sake.

134134775.review:
𝐄𝐧𝐝𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐫𝐚𝐠𝐞, 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐥 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐫, 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐟𝐮𝐫𝐲 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐝𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐬.

Let me set the scene - I'm no stranger to games of extreme difficulty, and despite faltering interest towards them in recent years due to a personal effort to put distance in my life from stress factors, I still find myself bouncing back to some of the ones I've seen as integral to my completion rate as an achievement hunter. I've never played a game that I didn't feel I'd at one point or another complete.. but Furi? I'd almost given up hope. 

I started my first run half a decade ago, to this date. I gave it a few odd attempts "The Line / The Scale, The Burst / The Edge and The Star each posed a challenge, and each caused me to put the game down for long periods of time." There'd always been some itch to come back to this game, I couldn't tell what it was, but no other game plagued my thoughts for not finishing it like this game did. It's not as if I had anything to prove in beating it, none of my friends have even played Furi. So there was no accolades or bragging rights in beating this game, let alone completing it to 100%.

But on my fourth attempt, something clicked. I didn't notice it initially, but I was entering the next chapter of my life as I had picked up the game. I'd gotten better at not giving into the rage that hard games used to fill me with, and I had new-found purpose in my life where I previously had nothing to strive for. This game served as my internal hurdle to bridging that gap in growth. If I could beat the game I considered to be one of the hardest I've played to date, then I could set out and achieve greater things in my life. I refused to take failure as my ultimatum. 

Coming back into it and shaking off the dust, I had to boot up a new run before I could even attempt to conquer The Star. Challenges that were massive hurdles in my previous runs showed their ugly faces once again. Yet it wasn't like the previous attempts. It was a slog-fest like the others, but I persevered this time, came back into my first save, and beat The Star. By a stroke of luck, I'd gone for my speed-run attempt next and didn't expect to get very far. However, holding those fights fresh in my mind, and the residual droplets of knowledge I'd gained over the years from Furi, I managed to smash both out in the same run. Suddenly it felt like I had a fighting chance to actually beat this game.

One of the greatest personal challenges I had aside from the general difficulty, was walking between each fight, and the dialogue that existed as nothing more than ways to get under your skin. But when I was doing my practice run for Furier, my relationship to these two events changed. The walking served as a way to detox from the stress of the last fight, as well as a means to come up with strategies towards the next fight. I began to harness not only that, but my new-found appreciation towards the dialogue for giving me clarity that I was the ultimate preventive factor to my success. (Quotes Below.)

With everything else under my belt, and the practice attempt now done, it was time to use the cultivation of everything I'd learned. It was tough, it was unfair, I was internally screaming and thought I'd have to attempt it a third time, but I did it. I got the S rank.

I've never felt a stronger catharsis and greater sense of self than I did getting to where I am now. Aside from my personal gripes in the two aforementioned factors, Furi delivers on every other element you'd want out of it. I still listen to the soundtrack despite no longer playing the game. I can only hope I'll have another experience like it in the form of a sequel, but in the event it never happens, I'll cherish the fact that it's had a strong role in shaping me to be the person I am now.

(You're fighting yourself, can't you see that? - The Line.
Mad little soldier. So much power. But so much pain. - The Scale.
You can fail, that's okay. It's the best you can do under the circumstances. - The Burst.
Excellence is not an art, it's pure habit. We are what we repeatedly do. - The Edge.)

Dont mind the 2 hours and half way achievements.
Did a %100 back on the PS4.
"This game is hard" is what most people would say but to be honest it just doesnt tell you HOW POWERFUL your character is.
One of the best soundtracks in a videogame ever award is shared by Hotline Miami and Furi right now and forever :D
Its very demanding tho.
On the Furier difficulty its immensely hard on some bosses.
Oh by the way this game has an anime like narration with a gameplay consisting only of BOSS FIGHTS.
So the game is actually short but them bosses arent easy.
There are two main ways to success in this game.
First is the classical memorizing the patterns altho bosses can go rando sometimes.
Second is to fundamentally understand each and every capabilities of your character(Rider).
I did the second way and it helps you a lot.
Gameplay is super fast and based on intense reflexes which I kind of got.
It has a VERY GOOD plot. Main story is very captivating. Narration is spot on.
It takes a lot of elements from mythology as well as science fiction so for me its huge win win.
Characters designed in a clever way. Use of color is amazing. Art direction is beautiful.
Ending had a good twist.
The music did I mention how legendary it was? oh I did...

10/10 for very specific people but 8/10 for people who are interested in an intense boss rush with one of the best ost ever. The trailer with the song "My Only Chance"still gives me the chills :D

About time I review this thing.
I discovered this game through the Soundtrack, featuring one of my favourite artists. A friend saw my amazement and decided to gift me the game.
I ragequit after 2 hours, and I wrote him some seriously angry messages about how unfair and bullshit the game was.
And I was playing on normal difficulty then.

Yeah, so I finished the game twice on the Furier difficulty and god damn what a great game it was. Learning the exact controls and figuring out the enemy patterns was an intense and horrifyingly exhausting journey but I feel like it paid off. The credit screen changes after you play Furier and it presents you with a very fun message. The satisfaction you get from actually beating the odds is immense.

Some enemies are better, some are worse. The soundtrack is PERFECT. Good god.
10/10
