I originally only came for the music, but once I started playing I couldn’t stop. 
Furi is essentially a boss fighter with each new boss having different strengths and weaknesses, it took me about 5-9 hours before beating the game in its entirety, and once I did beat it I immediately started playing again.
The voice acting is a 7/10, most people did absolutely amazing for their characters like The Voice, but I felt like others were lacking in some areas.
The music is a 10/10 every track was amazing to listen and fight to.
The gameplay is a 10/10 everything is really set up for the player, you just need skill and timing.
Animation is a 7/10 in some areas I felt the animation was slightly choppy and there is some clipping in several parts throughout the game,
But it doesn’t subtract in any way from the gameplay or story.
Story 10/10 I don’t believe I could say much about the story without spoiling it, but it’s good. Damn good.
If you could get any one game at any point in time, I think you should get Furi.

132483742.review:
[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Art style is cool and dreamlike; music keeps the same feel.

+ Controls are simple and responsive.

+ Music is fantastic and is the saving grace in the slower parts of game. (Unsurprisingly the boss called "The Song" has an absolute banger theme)

+ Each fight has a unique challenge and flow that requires the player to adapt.

+ Fights are challenging but are well balanced throughout; none of the fights felt unfair or like they went on for too long.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Story is largely unimportant; would've much preferred they dropped the shallow plot completely and really polished and expanded the core gameplay. Maybe go the "codex" route and add lore pieces collected by playing the game because currently it feels too forced and doesn't add enough value to the overall quality/enjoyment of the game.

- Between levels you are forced to slowly meander through linear paths with some exposition along the way. These portions very well could've and should've been cutscenes, especially since you can auto-walk through them anyways. There's very little reason to explore during these transition periods.

- The transitions are too long; it feels like the developer is begging you to look at the scenery, which is nice, don't get me wrong, but it definitely overstays its welcome at times. How many times do I need to watch the same floaty bridge be assembled as my character trots along? This is even more evident during long pauses between dialogue. If the dev wanted the player to be able to appreciate the environment at their own pace, make a separate exploration mode that consists of just the transitions or a video library that loops the transitions accessed after beating a section. If the dialogue was said at a normal cadence without long pauses, and the scenes were shorter to compensate, this would be a non-issue.


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  YES
DLC completed:  NO
Rating:  6 / 10 - Above Average

132335896.review:
This review is based purely off of my enjoyment of the game.

Furi is a game that is very heavily centred around gameplay. It's fast paced and combat includes melee, bullet hell and shooter aspects. I will get it out of the way and say, this aspect of the game is handled well. It flows, bosses have patterns of behaviour you can learn and ultimately master to progress onward. Each boss feels unique from each other and forces you to reconsider your approach to the fight, and the driving, electric beat of the music makes every action, every swing of your sword and dodge feel impressive. i can't really fault it too much.

But it's a game that feels as though it relies on combat to the detriment of the rest of the game. In between fights you let the game walk itself, intermittent dialogue being read out to you that tries to create this air of mystery as to who you are, yet for me never really managed to engage me due to its detached style of storytelling. This builds throughout to a conclusion which is the only non combat element of the game that I enjoyed, or rather thought was well done, where you walk the earth you have been trying to reach only to find that your very touch kills the plants beneath you.

The game itself is short and other than a brief trial with speedrunning certain bosses I didn't find much enjoyment in the idea of replaying the game so ultimately it was a rather brief experience.

This leads me to the conclusion that if you are someone looking for a fast paced gameplay focused game, go for it, it certainly has that, short though it is, but other than that, I think it's fair to give this game a miss.

132252123.review:
furi is a short game that merges elements from hack and slash and bullet hell games
and success in doing so by providing the player with a decent and fair challenge with an addicting fast paced gameplay
1-Gameplay
A. Core Gameplay
the gameplay consists of two cores.
the first one being the hack and slash elements which are
normal attack, charged attack evading etc.
for evading you can dodge or parry but the game wants you to parry and rewards you when you do it by healing you, and if you parry in the last second you enter a "perfect parry" which deals damage to the enemy that are equal to a 4 hit combo!
also you can parry almost every thing in the game and even reflect the bullets like a badass.
the other one are the bullet hell elements which are:
pistol shots and charged shots
charged shots can knock the enemies down from a very far distance which makes them quite useful sometimes so make sure to use them
B.Bosses
The game consists entirely of boss fights.
Which leads the player to expect each one of them to be unique which the the game does to a certain degree
first I'd like to talk about the bosses in general
every boss has more than two phases and each phase has two segments , I like to name them 360 segment and one-on-one segment.
the former being the segment where you can move freely and put as much space as you want between you and the boss the latter being the segment where there is a highlighted area which you can not leave
every boss uses in different way.
Now lets return to our main topic, remember when I said: "Which leads the player to expect each one of them to be unique which the the game does to a certain degree" the reason I said 'which the the game does to a certain degree'
is that in the last 3 bosses you feel that the games has no more ideas because the bosses mostly consists of the same attacks and moves which isn't too bad but of course is a problem.
other than that the first 6-7 bosses are very fun and test the player's skills.
2-Story
Yeaaah.... The story only makes the game longer and more boring so if you want something with a good story definitely don't buy and play this game, if you want an excellent story with an interesting set of characters I recommend playing Xenoblade 3!!!
3- Music
The game music type is one that I don't usually prefer a lot but it has some decent tracks.
4-art style/graphics/Animation
I absolutely loved the art style, it was cartoonish and very unique also there was a successful attempt to display the prison's several environments and atmosphere , the animation was good too
8/10
(subjective rating, based on enjoyment)

130991118.review:
A fantastic game with an incredible soundtrack, a robust artstyle and a refined gamplay loop designed around the fact that the game is 10 incredibly unique (both visualy and mechanically) boss fights in a row, wrapped up in a piquant narrative. Its a game that knew exactly what it wanted to be (boss fight simulator) and accomplishes that beautifuly with no frills or excess.

There's no upgrades, no skill trees, no unlocks, no powerups, no levels, no progression, no rng, nothing appart from pure unadulterated mechanical skill. The entire game is perfectly balanced around the moveset that you get at the start and the only thing that's going to change is how well you can use that moveset.

Its not as deep as devil may cry or as wide as monster hunter, but its just as long as it needs to be and a perfectly actualized experience that knows exactly what it wants to deliver and when to stop. 

One of the very few games I would consider "art" belonging in a museum simply because of how well all the elements (gameplay and non gameplay) work toogether both by themselves and with one another. 

There is nothing that needs to be removed, nothing that needs to be added, and nothing that needs to be changed. This is an actualized game.

Honestly just buy it for the soundtrack, because that alone is worth the money.

130855541.review:
Intro 
Bueno realmente Furi no es un juego que me pase por primera vez ahora al momento de escribir esta reseña sino que es un juego que ya me pase en Origin Access por el lejano 2016 sin embargo aquella vez lo hice con amigos y nos íbamos turnando algunos jefes por lo que quise darle otra vuelta ahora haciendolo completamente por mi mismo.
Gameplay
Diseño de niveles: El diseño de niveles de Furi es muy interesante ya que se plantea desde un punto dónde el jefe tiene la ventaja más no es imposible de vencerlo, varias de las arenas se limitan a áreas circulares vacías en la que es un enfrentamiento sin obstáculos de por medio sin embargo cuando es requerido los desarrolladores se pusieron ingeniosos con las arenas de combate.

Combate: El combate de Furi es EXCELENTE, el personaje responde de manera rápida y precisa, cuando mueres no es que el juego haya fallado en hacer tal o cual es enteramente tu culpa, no fuiste suficientemente rápido o no usaste los medios que el juego te da de manera eficiente.

Ambientacion

La banda sonora: La banda sonora no es una memorable más cumple con creces su propósito, la música de los jefes transmiten parte de su personalidad, no tiene nada que destacar pero hace un buen trabajo.

El apartado artístico: El apartado artístico de Furi si que me deja un poco frio, si bien sus graficos como tal no son (ni fueron) la gran cosa tampoco es que se haga demasiado con la dirección artística como para compensarlo, considero que es suficiente pero se podría haber hecho mas.

Los diálogos: Los diálogos que tenemos en su mayoría son del “hombre conejo” que nos ayuda a escapar desvelando y anticipando un poco la historia de lo que ira adelante y sobre todo nos da contexto de quienes somos o a quien nos vamos a enfrentar.

La historia: La historia es algo simple nada que no podamos dilucidar desde la primera hora de juego sin embargo entiendo que no se podría haber contado algo mas complejo es un boss rush de corta duración.

Los jefes: Obviamente los protagonistas de este juego, Furi es un boss rush, los jefes son lo mas importante, desafiantes y con una curva mas que aceptable (hasta el 8 boss que pega un salto de dificultad bestial) todos tienen su arena que transmite parte de lo que son si bien en todos los juegos los jefes suelen tener la “ventaja local” ya que luchamos contra ellos en sus territorios Furi lleva esto al gameplay (salvo excepciones como la de la francotiradora que aun me cuestiono porque hay muros que le hacen counter abiertamente como si quisiera perder) las arenas normalmente favorecen a los jefes pero como dije anteriormente aun permitiendo que se les pueda vencer (claro, duh).

Comentarios extras: Una pega personal que tuve con Furi es que no me gusta el rol del protagonista mudo que contempla y ni si quiera es capaz de cruzar una palabra con los jefes, siendo un boss rush y por su historia considero que se desaprovecharon muchos diálogos que podrían haber nutrido a la situación aunque considerando lo que es el protagonista al final entiendo que quieren reflejar que su personalidad es asi por lo que es, aunque considerando el final verdadero esta teoría se cae un poco a pedazos.

En conclusión: Furi es un juego que aun a dia de hoy puede darte unas 5-6 horas de diversión o aun mas si decides rejugarlo, es un juego muy solido que se controla exquisitamente y obliga al jugador a mejorar en si mismo y NO a mejorar el personaje.

That's what got me into Crystal Castles, CRIM3S, † CΛIN †, and other similar artist. Not to forget, I've also was bewitched by the works of Revolver Studio and loved the Hotline Miami series, so naturally I also adore Carpenter Brunt, M.O.O.N, and similar music artist. You could not and should not mention talk about talk about the game's without talking about the OST. FURI's OST, especially "My Only Chance" by Toxic Avenger is possibly my favorite video game OST. If the music recommendation and the emotions it comes with doesn't sell you my reasoning why I recommend this game, well I'll tell you where I stood at when I finally decided to blow the dust off this and give it a try. I like hard combat video games. I've played the hell out of the Dark Souls Trilogy and had around 400 hours in Elden Ring. /V/tards now this feeling, "having all this games but growing increasingly bored with gaming itself". This game hands down rekindled that flame in me. With only 10 Hours into this, I can see myself chasing the  achievements and combat mastery of such a indie title that gets my blood pumping again. On a personal level, I don't like playing the race game, but the Story Creator and Lead Artist, Takashi Okazaki, is into black culture as much as black men are into Dragon Ball Z. Attempting not to prattle on about representation, The Stranger quickly grew to become one of my favorite video game protagonist, not just through his bad ass actions, relentless attitude in a harsh environment, and riveting mystery that surrounded him; The Stranger enchanted me as a protagonist, and he gets extra points because he did this without playing the race game. Anyways, I loved, and continue to love FURI, and highly recommend taking up the challenge to escape the Jailers. Good Luck!

This is a high recommendation for anyone looking for a challenge.

130110944.review:
THIS GAME IS VERY PAINT BY NUMBERS

The game mechanics are frustratingly by the numbers. No hits on the boss during their attacks, only parry. You dodged the boss charged attack and want to hit them? Too damn bad. Range shot a bit to chip away at their health? Sorry this is the dodge part and the boss is shielded. I really wanted to enjoy this game because it looked great and had a pretty great soundtrack to go with the battle. But I cannot deal with something that refuses to let you play how you want. You either have to do it their way or you lose. 

Also your character has 3 lives. When you lose all of your health you hit the A button and you lose a life but you regenerate your heath so you can keep playing. But the boss also regenerates their health fully. These are bosses with 3, 4, or 5 different forms you have to beat, so if you're thinking hey it's ok that I died at this tough boss I'll use one of my lives and keep at it because I've taken a bunch of his health already, well you're in for a bad surprise.

The dodge option is delayed slightly but it is enough to cost you some cheap hits. The parry section will not let you doge and attack. You can only parry in that section, if you try to dodge and get behind the boss and get a couple of hits it, they will just disappear and reappear behind you and start their move set again.

Overall the game could be fun but it is just to frustratingly annoying by locking you into certain play styles and not letting you experiment and find your own way to win.

VERY PAINT BY NUMBERS

129788719.review:
A game that I liked more and more as it went on. To be honest, half the reason I even started this game was because of the absolutely amazing synthwave soundtrack, which I had been listening to on night drives long before even buying this game.

The game initially made a good, but not great impression on me. I love the aesthetics of the world the devs have created --- again, the music makes a huge difference here --, but I didn't really care for the somewhat aimless and angsty dialogue of both the narrator and of some of the bosses. Not that it really matters all that much: the walky bits and the exposition seem designed first and foremost to give you a breather in between the incredibly intense (and quite difficult) boss battles. And in that sense, they get the job done. 

To be honest, the reason this game initially put me off a bit was due to the timing of the blocks and parries. It's a classic case of simply needing to practice more, I will admit, but something about the way the timing for the blocking works in this game never really clicked with me, even by the end. I feel like I'm missing something with it. There is a visual and audio cue that says there is a blockable attack incoming, but you need to press the button a half-measure after that cue, [i]I think.[/i] But I somehow felt like this timing shifted from boss to boss, even though that's probably not really true, and I was just panicking pressing the button. I never really got the hang of it, and this led to some frustration with a number of bosses. 

[spoiler]Funnily enough, the one boss that is just literally a parry boss, the samurai dude near the end, was the one where the timing did somehow make perfect sense to me, and I beat him with ease on the first try. Some of the bosses before that, who had final phases that required a series of blocks lest the player be reset to the beginning and lose 10 minutes of progress, gave me a lot of trouble with the parrying though. There were a number of bosses I would have beaten the first time, if not for the required blocking chain at the very end of their encounters. Ah well.[/spoiler]

Anyway, regardless of this small gripe, I did really like this game. In the latter half, I think I even started to genuinely love the combat. The mechanics in this game feel tuned perfectly nearly 100% of the time, and so the game is fair in its toughness. I had never played a bullet hell game before, and in games like Dark Souls I tend to stick to rolling through everything, though I did beat Sekirô and felt I was pretty good at the blocking in that game. But in any case, Furi for me represented a pretty unknown type of gameplay experience, and the tightness of the controls combined with the visceral action and the absolutely amaze-balls soundtrack made me fly through the last 3 or so hours. In the beginning, I got tired of the game after one or two bosses, but by the time I had taken down the fourth one I was in my groove, and couldn't really put it down. I literally physically pumped my fist after beating some of the more intense battles as well.

Come for the soundtrack, stay for the heart-pumping action. I bought this game on sale, but if you like challenging but fair games, like so many of us do in the Dark Souls era of games, you can't go wrong with it for the full price either. It'll give you anywhere between 3 and 7-to-8-ish hours of satisfying punishment. (And potentially a lot more still if you get into the speed-running or the extra challenge content, I suppose.) Recommended!

129012861.review:
Furi is a pretty unique and intriguing game. For my first actual attempt at playing a bullethell game, I mostly found it to be a pretty fun, cinematic experience. That being said though, its not all perfect.

I can't say anything about the plot without pretty much spoiling it, but I will say it reminded me a lot of Shadow of the Colossus in its story themes and progression. It's told in a solid way and kept me engaged all throughout with many well done twists and turns.

Visually, its no showstopper, but for a small team, its really good. The environments are really gorgeous and the games art-style is really cool.

To talk on sound design, the music in this game is pretty phenomenal. It fits the sci-fi space aesthetic really well and almost every single track slaps.

Gameplay wise, its a bullethell game with some twists thrown in. The game primarily takes place in two different styles, overhead combat with you dealing ranged damage whilst dodging waves of projectiles. When your enemies have been weakened, the game will enter into a close camera mode and will shift its focus to a more close quartered, melee oriented fighting style. Here, the game focuses a lot more on parrying and reading enemy movement. The two styles work well enough and combined with the music, makes for some high adrenaline and fun gameplay.

As for the difficulty, its far from one of the most difficult games I've played. For your average player, I would say it sits somewhere in the middle. Generally, its not controller breaking difficult, but if you lose focus and let your guard down, this game can whoop your ass. If I had one critique for the difficulty, its that the curve it presents is all over the goddamn place. Rather than the game starting easy and getting harder as it goes, instead Furi just kinda does whatever the hell it wants. Some fights are hard, where's others are total push-overs. The final two boss fights in the main campaign I found to be both extremely easy, although for the late one, that might've been done on purpose. But then there's a secret boss which is fought only via an alternate ending, and this boss in particular completely dumps on every other boss in the game and is extremely difficult. Part of this is why I personally opted out of doing the alternate ending.

I beat the game in about 2 hours and 40 minutes, making it quite short. In that playtime I found the game engaging, but its challenge was inconsistent and I didn't find myself struggling that much. The alternate boss however, is a massive spike in difficulty and I wouldn't say the game prepares you for it at all as nothing in the base game comes even close to it. Oh yeah, and if you do plan on playing this game, I would highly recommend taking the games advice and playing on a controller. All in all the pc controls aren't awful, but after beating the entire game with them, I can say they aren't as intuitive as they should be.

EDIT: To add an additional point, I did decide to make an additional attempt at beating the alternate boss and I've decided, yeah, it isn't worth it. To put it in perspective, I've spent probably close to an hour and a half so far attempting to beat it, not far off what it took me to beat the entire game and I still haven't gotten anywhere near defeating it. Ordinarily I'd just chock it up to me being too impatient to beat them, but in all honesty, its kinda just a bullshit fight. Its incredibly long and you're given barely any additional health at all throughout, basically meaning if you wanna beat them, you gotta do each sequence almost dead perfect, which really isn't fun or satisfying. I don't consider it a fun or productive use of my time spending hours upon hours on a single boss fight tbh, so yeah I'm not gonna bother doing it.

All in all, this is a unique and highly engaging game. If you are to play it, I'd probably recommend it on a sale, seeing as you can beat it very quickly.

125266076.review:
Furi is a game about mastery. You cannot beat this game without becoming a master of its base mechanics.

If that is intimidating, good, that means you are human. As it turns out, Furi is also a game about humanity. 

Furi is an excellent game, but not for everyone. If you can find value in the intrinsic pursuit of mastery, and the creeping corruption of compassion, this game is for you. If you can't imagine yourself devoting time to learning to press buttons at the right time in a computer game, then this game isn't for you. 

Your character is set up as an unstoppable weapon of destruction, one who has already mastered killing. You are alien to the other characters of this game. None of them really stand a chance against you, every challenge they pose can be triumphed with time and effort. And unfortunately for them, they stand in your way.

The mechanics of the game are beautiful in their simplicity. You're given a big fuck-you sword and a quick eat-this gun. With the sword, you can parry and attack (and also boost or charge but that's optional). With the gun, you can fire, which damages foes or destroys their projectiles (you can also charge it but that's both optional and inefficient). You can dodge. With just these tools, you can beat the game.

It's more nuanced than that, of course. You don't just use these tools, you master them. You feel your toolkit as intuitively as you breathe, you parry as quickly as you blink, you shoot at subconsciously as your heart beats. This comes with practice, with success, with failure. Each boss's challenge becomes more layered and complex as it progresses, such that you'll be surprised how easy the beginning phases are when you replay them, despite them handing you your ass only minutes before. You figure out what works and what doesn't, and you apply it of your own volition to succeed. 

While you continue your slaughter, you start to understand why you started the game in prison. You realize these people in your way have deeply personal reasons to be there, depriving you of your freedom. You begin to feel humanity poking through your cold, machine-like exterior. Only once you reach the ending will you realize you already lost, your enemies accomplished their goals without even meaning to. Through example, they restored your humanity.

Furi's gameplay is punishing. Failing to be perfect will take away your hit points, and losing too many hit points will take away your lives, and losing too many lives will take away your progress. This is all baked into the design philosophy of Furi. Failing to be perfect is only an issue when you do it continually. Otherwise, being perfect actually restores your hit points, allowing you to be imperfect more. Losing a life allows you to keep practicing, to keep improving and mastering the challenge. Losing progress takes you back to the beginning of the boss, where you face the same challenge but less complex, and see for yourself how much you've improved. You're not meant to be afraid of these outcomes, as both you and your character are set up to keep trying for as long as it takes. 

"Excellence is not an art, it's pure habit. We are what we repeatedly do." Play Furi.

125164017.review:
No progression?  No loadout options? Forced parries?

On the surface, there are a LOT of elements to Furi that would suggest its not my type of game.  But holy hell, I'm only two hours in and already feel like I got my $ worth (If you like synth/vapor/retrowave at all, by this game simply for the OST)

 Despite having relatively limited controls, the constant shifts in boss tactics require you to fully maximize the effectiveness of your moveset.  The health/parry mechanic makes it so that you are truly never out of any fight and makes it possible for you to completely turn the tide of any given battle with proper focus.  

It also doesn't overly penalize you for losses on the standard difficulty, given the learning curve, its nice you are allowed to continue from the existing boss instead of run it all back.  Given how long each fight can last, this is definitely a boon to the learning curve.  The difficulty increase across each boss is also extremely balanced, at no point has any defeat made me feel the boss is unfair or unbeatable.

This won't ever be a 1000+ hour game for me, the combination of a shorter game + how demanding it is to play will cap how much time I put into it.  But for the hours I do spend on the game, I can be certain it will be full of intense, heart-pounding moments that are hard to replicate.  Its easy to put somebody on the edge of their seat, its another thing to keep them there and this game fully delivers on the latter

125003357.review:
It was July 2016. I'm in my sophmore year of high school. I hop on my PS4 to see what were the free PS+ games of the month. Furi was one of them. It looked super interesting and so I downloaded it. 

Little did I know that I'd still be playing this game 6 years later. 

To say this game made a huge impact on my life is an understatement of the highest degree. 

To this day this has been one of, if not, my favorite game of all time. The artstyle is simple but effective and colorful. Easy on the eyes too. The gameplay is fun, fast, challenging and exciting (and sometimes mildy infuriating lol). And to top it all off, this soundtrack led me to a synthwave rabbit hole. Now a good 50% of all of my songs on my personal playlist are just filled with tracks from Waveshaper, Carpenter Brut, Danger, and many others. 

This also started my descent into a game rabbit hole. This game led me to other gems I never played before. Hotline Miami and Katana Zero to be more specific. These games are exactly what I was looking for; challenging gameplay with banger soundtracks. 

And none of this would've ever happened if it weren't for that fateful day in July 2016. 

6 years later I'm still trying to beat my personal best records (and I have, but I still want to get better.) 

6 years later I'm still playing the soundtrack everywhere I go.

And the Onnamusha update gave this game a breath of fresh air that I didn't even think it needed, but it basically made my mentality go back to where it was on the first day I played it; ultra excited, wanting to get better at it, begging for more. 

If you haven't played this game, you're doing yourself a disservice. 

Here's to 6 more years. 

TLDR; 10/10 will kill jailer again

The boss fights are tedious, long, and there is nothing to do in this game in between the boss fights except "walk" from one fight to the next while the narrator talks at you in a cryptic manner. I put walk in quotes because you might as well let the game auto walk for you. 

I like difficult games and I am ok with the fact that I am not very good at this game. There's just no way to fine tune the difficulty of this game so that you can practice more and get better. All the boss fights are essentially the same. You character doesn't evolve in any way so you just have to use the same limited attacks to knock health off the boss and use dodge/block/parry to survive. Bosses can be tedious and take a long time to beat if you are not great, and you often have to grind through the early phases of each fight that are too easy in order to practice the harder, later phases of each battle. I really think they could have done a better job fine tuning the difficulty modes in the game.

Unlike other difficult games (e.g. monolith, hades) where there is some reward that carries over for playing the game and failing, there is nothing to this. You just have to keep trying until you get better. I've read that finishing the game unlocks more but the story and mechanics are dull so and I not sure I will stick with this.

122537038.review:
When Furi came out, I ignored it - just like The Sexy Brutale. Except while I skipped over TSB because of the title, I skipped over Furi because of the description. "The jailer is the key, kill him and you'll be free"? Why am I in jail, why do I need to kill someone to get out? Pass.

And of course, just like in the case of The Sexy Brutale, this was a criminally bad decision. Because not only Furi is an amazing game, the description is actually very apt and sets the tone quite well. Granted, it's not very descriptive of the game, and the screenshots just show a bunch of neon anime fighting and flashing lights... so I'll describe the game for you instead, hoping that you won't end up making the same mistake as me.

[h1]Well, what is it?[/h1]
In one sentence: Narrative-driven boss rush alternating between top-down bullet hell and close up melee sections.

[b]Narrative-driven[/b] means that the game not only has a story, it's also quite directly woven into the very core of the game. The driving question is "who are you, and why are you locked up?" - and the characters, that is your opponents (and your singular unlikely ally) talk to you a lot before and during the fight (not after, since they're dead). Most of it is banter, but eventually you start to form a picture of what's happening. And it's a very emotionally potent story where narration, combat, environment and music come together in a powerful way.

[b]Boss rush[/b] means exactly what it sounds like. You only fight against bosses, although the fights are separated by a bit of a walk between the areas, during which you get to take in the scenery and listen to some helpful exposition from your friend.

[b]Alternating between top-down bullet hell[/b] - each boss has several health bars. You deplete each one through two sections. The first one consists of the boss shooting stuff at you, while you avoid their projectiles and shoot back, occasionally getting in close for a melee strike. It's more bullet purgatory rather than bullet hell, it's not so bad. This one is played in top-down perspective for obvious reasons.

[b]And close up melee sections[/b] - once you've finished a bullet hell section you get to get close and personal, and you exchange your gun for your laser blade. The camera zooms in, the effective arena shrinks to a small area around your opponent, and the fight becomes all about parrying, avoiding ground-based AoEs and counterattacking, occasionally charging your blade for a power attack. Top ten anime fights: the game.

[h1]Okay, but is it good?[/h1]
I mean, I obviously like it. Can anything be considered objectively good or bad? Gah, fine, I'll cut the crap.

- It's rather challenging; I've played harder games, but Furi is harder than most. I found it just right, considering the subject matter.
- it's very fast! Do you like fast games? This is fast. 
- the fights are varied, and generally don't reuse mechanics. No boredom here.
- the music is some great French electro/synth made by Danger, Carpenter Brut and The Toxic Avenger.
- the story is suspenseful, emotional and keeps you guessing until the very end. It's mostly given to you piecemeal by boss dialogue, but there's also some quality visual storytelling.
- it's pretty, at least I think so. Cyberpunk afro samurai.
- and of course the fighting is tight and satisfying.

Would you say that those things are good? Then yes, this game is good. 

[h1]My Only Chance to Make This Right[/h1]
This sentence - when you understand its true meaning - does an excellent job of showcasing the aesthetic symmetry and general theme of the story. Also, if you haven't played this game, I'm hoping that this review will make this right, and convince you to play it. Yeah? Okay, that was a bit too pretentious...

Aaanyway, as a closing statement I'd like to bring the attention that the game's developers - The Game Bakers - are French, but they cooperated with Takashi Okazaki, the mangaka behind Afro Samurai. He's the one who did the character design, and it shows. So Furi is a result of an unlikely French-Japanese cooperation. I wouldn't mind seeing more of such team ups.

So yeah, go ahead! Get it, play it, and most importantly, enjoy!

The game is split in two parts.
1. Bossfights of mediocre enjoyment.
2. Extremely long, tedious, boring, unnecessary, time-padding walking sequences during which you have to listen to some fucking bunny-man who says a bunch of things completely irrelevant to anything in your life in the most uninteresting way possible.

Aside from that, graphics are really bad. While from the distance they might seem minimalistic and passable enough, whenever the game closes up on models you are forced to admire how ugly they are. And you will watch them a lot during the walking sequences. Unskippable walking sequences.

tl;dr: overhyped and overpriced; whatever you might seek in video games, it's done better in other titles.

122169822.review:
First impressions were very bad. I don't like bullet hell shooters, the story seemed deliberately obtuse and pretentious, and the way the game calls its base difficulty 'Promenade' as if it's mocking you for not being immediately godlike at it as soon as you pick it up all added up to a hard rage quit five years ago. 

However upon revisiting it this year I found one of the most simple but rewarding and impactful gaming experiences in the last few years. 

The bad first: 
The second boss. A huge difficulty spike from the first, it's a tremendously long fight in a visually bland environment against an uninteresting opponent with a multitude of poorly-explained mechanics. No wonder I stopped here on my first crack at the game.
The third boss. How do you make 'a master of time' boring? Like this! Do almost nothing with the fascinating premise and chalk it up to standing almost totally still in the back of the arena endlessly shooting at an unmoving bullet sponge. 
Walking. Why isn't it just a cutscene? I get that it gives us an auto-walk button for between the fights, but if anything that underlines how bad the controls for these little jaunts are. They're effective ways to build up the bosses through intriguing exposition but either give us controls that aren't shit or take control away altogether for a few minutes. It's good for de-stressing post-battle anyway.
My cat. Won't stop jumping in my lap when I'm playing. >:(

Now the good: 
Every other boss I haven't mentioned yet is a banger. Each one feels unique and challenging (some more than others), but epic enough that by the time the fight's over you feel accomplished, like you really got to know your enemy. Blending bullet hell shooting with lightning-fast melee combat means that each boss demands a variety of skills, from dodging to blocking to sniping to shooting out enemy projectiles to simply being the fastest one on the draw (for both your sword and your gun). 
The visuals. Not just the unique art design for each character and environment, not just the wildly varied color pallette, not just the well-rendered graphics, but how all of it comes together. This could have come dangerously close to being a visually messy game, but I was consistently impressed by how crisp and clean everything was. By drawing sharp lines between soft colors, Furi never loses clarity.
The sound. A soundtrack as pulsating and vibrant as its gameplay but surprisingly never distracts you from the action works hand in hand with brilliant audio cues to immerse you in this game's bizarre, action-packed world.
The story. While a little obnoxiously cryptic at first (well, at least to someone who doesn't like David Lynch movies), Furi's narrative becomes more solid as it goes along, and in a rare case (so rare in fact I haven't seen it since Spec Ops: The Line), I found each ending equally satisfying, even the bad ending. There's a surprising amount of story to tell here. Throughout the game you are constantly verbally (and of course physically) bashed by everyone you meet, so do you sue for peace, do you prove them wrong, or do you show them that if you treat someone like the villain long enough, they'll eventually become one?
My cat. She calms me down after boss 9's stupid turrets piss me off again.

Overall, 8/10. Solid recommendation, especially if you have my cat, which you don't. I'm not giving her to you. Find your own cat, piss off.

122167077.review: Furi's best aspect is the combat against bosses, and I really enjoy this part of the game. I like every boss fight (though some not as much as the others), and aside from the dodge's invincibility frames feeling unreliable it feels great to play. The walking sections can get kind of tedious sometimes, but I do like how they serve as a build-up to the next fight. I really like the challenge this game has even if it gets a little too hard for my tastes, and I will probably do a Furier run sometime in the future. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys very challenging combat-focused games.

121820364.review:
I wasn't sure if I'd ever write a Steam review, but this game convinced me to start. I've played a lot of great games that I could talk about for hours, but never one as well-rounded as this. You can tell the developers spent exactly the right amount of time on almost every aspect of the game- nothing is over- or under-developed. It's difficult, yes- that you've likely already heard. But PLEASE do not let that discourage you whatsoever. It will be hard, but it will get harder step by step. I never noticed a sharp difficulty spike. Impressively, playing on the Furier difficulty was also a smooth transition- the first fight on Furier gave me just as much challenge as the last on Furi difficulty. Not to mention the DLC, some of which is now free, effectively doubles the content of the game by adding an entirely new way to play that is somehow still just as fun.
Overall, I really really like this game. If you're like me, you agonize over game prices because money is hard to part with. If you want to wait for a sale, well, that is the financially smartest thing to do, after all. But I would pay more than $20 just to be able to experience this for the first time again.

121758035.review:
Furi was fun. Bought this game back in 2017, played it for 6 hours and didn't come further than number 8. Stopped playing for the longest while because I wasn't having fun anymore. Yesterday, I gave the game another try 'cause Furi completely fit the type of game I felt like playing. Hard, but satisfying to finish by showing patience and perserverance. Played from scratch again. Now, 5 years later, I suddenly beat the game in 3 hours. And I was having fun.

Once you get the hang of the mechanics, this game can be quite satisfying. You have to show some patience with the bullet hell stuff but other than that, it's not crazy hard[spoiler]honestly: shoot at all times, parry, dodge, and the game wil be a breeze[/spoiler], relatively short but definitely sweet. But that's precisely why this game was so satisfying and fun to play. (Especially the last two bosses before the credits were pretty easy - those were [i]actually[/i] pushovers.) The story is a bit vague at the start but starts to makes sense only at the ending. Doesn't offer much, but that's obviously not what the game is about. Has some replayablity if you are really looking for a challenge - harder difficulty and different modes. DLC for an extra battle[spoiler] and at least another one. Haven't beaten that one, but if you finish the first boss on furi difficulty, you get another one on furier difficulty[/spoiler], and they recently (after 5 years!) added another DLC for a different playable character, but I've heard she doesn't add much to the game.


All that to say - if you are into difficult, but not [i]too[/i] difficult, boss battles with banging music, art and aesthetics, this is for you. Learn to be patient and observant, and the game will be a breeze.

The game has a simple yet effective objective at hand. You break out of your cell and kill bosses. The idea seems fine at first, however, as you battle against the first boss, you realise that it's not a combat game. It is more of a puzzle game where you have to repeat several steps over and over again. While you have a lot of mechanics the game simply doesn't let you use them freely. You have the ability to melee your opponents but only during certain moments. The dodge/dash mechanic is also not good, as I expect the character to move towards where I'm pressing on my keyboard and not my mouse pointer as I am unable to notice it in a densely populated hell with flying bullets and particles. 

Additionally, the cut scenes are really stretched out to a point that they no longer tell a story but rather feel dull and unnecessary. The dialogue isn't interesting, and the bosses feel one dimensional, with cheesy lines.

Controls     - 8/10

Honestly, this is not the game for me. I felt the "bosses only" style of game play was tedious and I stopped having fun very quickly. The art style and controls are interesting enough, but with 3 hours in I found the difficulty curve was too high to be enjoyable and I was not at all motivated by the almost zero plot or story the game was pushing. It is clear enough to me that developers did take some time to create some kind of "edgy" world, I just didn't care for it or how much I had to practice the game to get a few crumbs.

To be clear, hard games can be a ton of fun, but I prefer to have the difficult increased over some time or to at least have some more variety in how I practice playing the game (i.e. just replaying the same boss again and again with literally nothing else in the game is frustrating and boring).

When the fundamental structure of the game is the problem, time to uninstall this and be bummed I missed the window to get a refund.

118680391.review:
I'll start with my minor nitpicks, that way I can end this review on a high note.

[list]
[*] Between each fight, there's a ~3 minute long walking section where one of the characters talks to you in order to develop the story. This is fine, but during these sections, your movement is slowed to a crawl. If they had allowed you to sprint, then I think it would've felt a lot less frustrating, even if they took the same amount of time.
[*] In the aforementioned walking sections, the camera jumps around to fixed points rather than following you. This sets up some cool shots, but it makes me feel disconnected from my character, and it makes walking around annoying since the direction that the camera is facing is constantly shifting. There is an auto-walk button so you don't have to deal with that, but that just makes me feel even more disconnected.
[*] When you beat the game on Furier (the harder difficulty), the game gives you a message thanking you for playing it "the right way," which may be the single most pretentious thing I've heard from a game.
[/list]

Now for the good stuff. 

[list]
[*] The combat is super fast, responsive, and satisfying. There's truly no feeling like reading a boss' attacks and dodging, parrying, and attacking them back with perfect precision. It really makes me wish there was a PvP mode where you could duel other players.
[*] The story is great. I was not expecting a fast, no-nonsense fighting game like this to have a story at all, much less a good one, but it's surprisingly intriguing.
[*] The soundtrack is AWESOME. I actually found the game because of the music. It's composed by some of the best synth artists out there, including The Toxic Avenger, Scattle, Lorn, Waveshaper, and Carpenter Brut. Easily my favorite OST from any game.
[*] The game is very replayable. You can play the story mode multiple times to chase a better score, there's the harder Furier mode that you unlock after your first playthrough, and there's the Speedrun mode that tracks your time and skips all of the cutscenes and walking sections.

10/10, this game feels like it was made for me.

118673112.review:
Previously played the original, vanilla version on PS4 when it was on PS+ and am back to say that Furi only gets better every time I go back. The new DLC character Onna is neato, and a cool reimagining of the gameplay experience that makes for a fresh revisit.

The DLC is unlike the situation in many games where the newly-added thing outclasses all else. Here, the new character is not something I see much reason to compare to and call superior to the original protagonist's gameplay style: it's an equally-good different way to play that stands on its own two legs. Better still is that it accomplishes that while building nicely from a base of the same mechanical groundwork that makes Furi so damn fun in the first place.

I love this game, and if the original is Kanto, the DLC is like the Johto revisit, a fresh walk down a beloved backdrop.

Where in this case, said backdrop is an aggro, cel-shaded, twitchy-responsive, pulse-pounder of a twin stick shooter/arena combat hybrid. One whose larger-than-life darksynth masterpiece OST feels like the video game version of Pink Floyd making a film to accompany The Wall. Which isn't to piss people off in saying that The Wall and Furi are equals, but in that Furi is similarly a prime example of "take incredible music: build something around it that elevates it even higher." Like the best art, this game is evergreen, and well worth a first foray or a revisit if you've yet to try the DLC.

118606528.review:
While I know it's easy to demean a piece of work by saying its "style over substance", I think that is unfair if the core mechanics or story is solid. Furi seemed like it would be up my alley, as I like "stylized" games as well as hack and slashers, but it slowly drained what good will I had as I continued to grapple with its broken mechanics. 

First of all, the good stuff. The games has fantastic visuals, very unique boss designs (and fights), and a stellar electronica soundtrack. While I know many have complained about the long walking sections between boss fights, I don't mind them so much as they provide a quiet contrast that is needed against the bombastic duels with the jailers. While the camera can be a problem, with just one button press you can have your character "auto walk" through the environment. 

Unfortunately, the bad stuff is the core of the game itself: the mechanics. The dodging, parrying, and shooting are all flawed. The dodging acts as your moment of invincibility as well. Since certain attacks can only be dodged through, you will be using this a lot. However, the dodge can be very finicky and often times I have found myself dodging in a wrong direction or overshooting my mark with it. The parry is even worse. When a parry is done successfully, you recover some energy and can even break the bosses combo. The problem is that your guard to parry lasts barely a second and every boss will often hesitate before melee attacking. This has led to me most of the time seeing the boss attack, hit the button to parry, only for it to end right as the boss attacks. I have always hated parrying in games. Just make a "guard" where if it is done at the correct time, you can parry. Otherwise, the enemy should do less damage while your on guard. Lastly, the gun is VERY awkward to use. If using a controller, you have to hold down R3 to use it and move the stick in the direction you're firing. This makes the 3rd boss of the game very awkward since the gun plays a major role in that fight. 

Despite these flaws, it didn't keep me from enjoying the boss fights. Most of the times, the gun was not needed and I had plenty of room and time to prepare a dodge. I used the gun when I felt like it and I could often "run away" from the bosses melee attacks. Their is a measure of mercy in these long boss fights. Bosses will often have multiple phases which can wear on a player as they are learning the patterns. When the players beats a bosses phase, they will receive an additional life if they have lost one and have their energy filled up, but the opposite is true as well. If the boss depletes your energy, you have to start the phase over again. This provides a good balance between being hard and being far. The bosses have a "top down" view and focus on both melee and bullet hell which is a fun an unique experience. 

It's just too bad the game flushes all of that down the toilet with the "duels" at the end of each boss phase. It is here where every single problem with the game become exponentially worse. 

When you deplete a bosses life bar, you will enter into a "duel" with them where you are in an enclosed field and the camera shift to a closer view, and the boss gains their health back. I cannot tell you how many times I finished a normal boss phase with little to no damage, only to lose it all and have to repeat the whole phase because of these duels. Generally, the boss will either melee attack you or do an arena attack with only a small sliver of the arena being safe. This is where the game falls apart. Everything is so chaotic and blends together and the "signals" for the attack usually blend in with the more stylish backgrounds. You will likely lose most of your health due to the melee attacks and not full dodging the arena swipes since the red that shows their trajectory can often blend with the color of the arena. Whenever I won these duels, it was usually luck rather than any sort of skill. And of course, if you lose your health, you have to repeat the boss phase AND the duel. 

Despite liking a lot about this game, those duels killed any goodwill I had for it or desire to continue going. While I do enjoy hard games, I play games to unwind and not to get stressed or angry. Whenever I lose in a difficult game, I want it to be because I made a mistake or got cocky, not because the game stacked the deck against me through faulty mechanics and screwing with my senses. 

If you want a stylized, difficult, boss game, go with Cuphead. It is much smoother and satisfying in its gameplay and mechanics. Oh and PS: having trophies earned for dying numerous times with the message being "git gud" is one of the most pedantic things imaginable, especially if your game has poor mechanics and cheap difficulty.

118353075.review:
Furi is a double-digit sequence of boss fights, tied together by cinematics and loosely-interactive travel sequences. Its not directly comparable to any one game, but it has elements of Shadow of the Colossus, Dark Souls, and Bullet Hell.

Games are generally either about the journey or about mastery. Furi is about mastery. It has journey elements, in that you just need to squeeze out one win against each boss to finish the game. However, the game truly comes to life for those who decide that they want to master it: hard mode, S-ranks, and speed runs. Furi hits that sweet spot between "challenging" and "frustrating".

The soundtrack is great, the story is simple but satisfying, and the control is phenomenal. I can't understand why anyone would leave a bad review unless he knowingly played a game outside his tastes.

117902419.review:
Furi is an incredibly satisfying bullet hell that is not ashamed by how simple it is. The game is a boss rush with nothing in between but brief respites filled by traversing an otherwise empty world. A lesser game would feel the need to try and hide the lack of variety in content by making each boss as radically different as possible. Furi doesn't do this. 

There is a consistency in the rules of the duel oriented world of Furi that compliments it's rigidity in a way that makes you not care that your character never really develops in terms of it's abilities. You as a player evolve, and the later bosses aren't easier because all of a sudden your character is a super high level, or because you have 8 different kinds of rocket launchers, it's because you've become so educated on the anatomy of the adversaries that learning a new set of timings and dodging patterns has grown trivial.

Often this leads to an anti-climatic end. The description I've given has probably already led you to draw comparisons to Shadow of The Colossus. Another fantastic game, but SotC, at least in my opinion, has an anti-climatic end from a gameplay standpoint, as you've just become so well versed in the art of defeating these titans that the last few have less impact. Without spoiling much, I will just say that the true final boss of this game is such a pure test of everything you've learned up until that point that even with how quickly you likely dispatched with the couple of foes before it, you will still be asked to demonstrate yourself so adeptly that it gives the games conclusion the kind of satisfying feeling it deserves. That in conjunction with it's difference in what it's relevance is to the story is leads to it being exactly the right kind of hair raising final boss a game like this needs.

Unfortunately, unlike SotC, the intermittent passages of land traversal are not the kind of atmospheric, perspective building set pieces they are in that game. Obnoxious camera angle changes, less than sluggish movement in the sections, and a complete lack of any sort of feeling of connectivity to the world itself make it easily the worst part of the game. It's truly a shame, as I find the dialogue provided by your companion character to be well written and interesting, and there's not much that hasn't already been said about how fantastic the soundtrack to the game is. So, any excuse to get to listen to that more should be welcomed. It's really a shame, as I think the developers were right to think something like that is necessary in a boss rush game like this, but this just wasn't the way to do it.

All in all, a masterclass in how to make the most out of a single concept.

117536457.review:
Stick with me here, this is a long one.

There's a lot to like about Furi, and a lot more to dislike. It's a shame too, because behind the veil of slipshod controls, filler "cutscenes", and easy, often tedious boss fights, there's a legitimately good game. For the sake of transparency, I am writing this review after playing through the entire game on normal difficulty.

I'll start with the positives:

- The music is fantastic. This is pretty much a given if you've watched even one trailer, but this game legitimately has one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a while.

- None of the boss fights are samey; each boss has their own attacks, gimmicks, arena, and personality. I can only think of a few moments where two bosses shared a similar attack, aside from simple attacks that most of the bosses have, like where they just shoot a couple bullets at you. For the most part, they're all unique, and I like that a lot.

- The visual style and voice acting are decent. They could both be a bit more polished in my opinion, but they're certainly nowhere near bad.

- The parrying, melee combat, and normal gun firing all feel and work great. The mechanic of regaining health when you parry is honestly a stroke of genius, and the game would be completely different without it. Because of that, it feels legitimately rewarding when you do a chain of three, four, or five parries in a row and lay down a powerful melee counterattack that knocks the boss on their ass, and getting a perfect parry feels especially good. The gun firing isn't anything special, but it does the job and it does it well, and I'm not really looking for anything more than "bullets get fired" when it comes to a basic ranged attack.

And now, for the negatives:

- The controls suck, at least on mouse and keyboard. The game tells you flat out that a console controller is highly recommended, but I don't have one, so I had to stick with the default PC control scheme. The dodging is the most obviously flawed control since it's controlled by where your cursor is positioned rather than what direction you're moving in, which consistently screwed me over. I was able to get accustomed to it, but just barely, and even with that more subjective issue it's still an objectively bad design choice since where you aim your gun is also controlled by your cursor. So, if a boss is to the north of you, and you're getting hit by wide attacks from east and west that you can't strafe around, you have to take your cursor off the boss, dodge sideways by aiming sideways, and then refocus your cursor on the boss and start firing at them again. On paper it doesn't sound terrible, but in practice it's a serious nuisance.

- The dodging is also terrible because, for some inane reason, they decided to implement a charged dodge. This move is literally never useful, at least in the base game on normal difficulty, and because they added this, your dodge only comes out once you let go of the spacebar rather than when you pressed it. This causes pretty noticeable lag regarding when you actually dodge, and can screw you over if you're not careful. Also, charging a dodge locks you in place, for some reason.

- There are charged versions of the melee attack and the ranged attack too, and they're only slightly more useful than the wholly useless charged dodge. I can count on one hand the number of times I used the charged slash throughout the entire game, and the charged fire is literally only useful on the last fight in the game, where it's changed from a mediocre charged projectile to a goddamn laser beam that ends up being the most consistent way to damage the boss out of everything in your arsenal. Of course, the game does not inform you that you now have this surprisingly useful laser beam; I figured this out accidentally, when I mistakenly pressed and held the charge shot button.

- As good as melee combat feels, you pretty much exclusively use it for counterattacking, such as when you manage to parry an attack, or after a boss does a big sweeping attack that makes them let their guard down. If you try to hit the boss while their guard is up, they either just won't react, or they'll try and punish you for it, which you can usually parry if you're fast enough. This design choice does make sense to an extent, so I can't get too mad about it, but I still found it annoying.

- Despite the downright horrible dodging and the fact that half of your abilities are generally useless, this game is still REALLY easy. I think I lost to a boss twice throughout the entire game, once on the third to last boss, and once on the final boss. Outside of those mistakes, I had virtually no trouble beating every boss in this game. 
As a side note, both of these bosses are notable for changing up the style of gameplay completely; the third to last boss is a strictly melee/parrying oriented fight, and the final boss is a strictly gunfire oriented fight.

-Despite this game being REALLY easy, it's also REALLY tedious, to a genuinely unacceptable degree. The biggest offender are the "paths" you walk down after beating every boss, which are really nothing more than mangled, maddeningly boring, unskippable cutscenes. All you have to do is press the spacebar, and the game automatically has your character traipse through these huge swaths of empty nothingness while a man wearing a rabbit mask and holding a microphone stand teleports around, spoon-feeding you exposition about whatever threat you're going to be facing next. It's boring, it's unnecessary, and it makes me actually dread beating the boss I'm currently facing because I know another five minutes or so of waiting around and twiddling my thumbs is all I have to look forward to next.
The boss fights are admittedly less tedious, but they still have their moments, such as when bosses do these huge bullet hell attacks on their last life that they're completely invincible for the entire duration of. If you're looking for a boss fight that IS tedious from start to finish, the sniper boss is by far the biggest offender, and it makes her fight easily the most annoying, exhausting fight in the game.

Those are the biggest negatives, but there are still two pretty egregious offenses that I'll talk about here. They might be a bit spoiler-y to some people, but there really isn't much to spoil story-wise or otherwise in this game, so I'm not going to bother hiding them with a spoiler tag.

- Right before the sixth boss, you'll be asked to stay with a female NPC rather than continuing on your quest to escape the prison. If you do decide to stay with her (by waiting around and doing nothing for a minute or two), THE GAME ENDS. This gives you one of the three endings of the game, all of which you will need if you want to 100% the game, and you are required to play through the entire game again if you want to face the four or five bosses that come after this scene.

- In the post credits sequence, after having this entire game hand me nothing but slow overworld travel through fixed camera angles, Resident Evil-style, the game finally shows off that it was in fact capable of fast, fun overworld maneuvering with a freely controlled camera all along, and that it could have made it work wonderfully. This isn't so much a mechanical issue as it is a flat out insult. You're telling me I could have been dashing my way between the bosses like this the entire game, and instead you made me move like a snail and deal with fixed, jarring cameras just so you could "build more suspense" and have your funny rabbit man teleport around like his name is Sans Undertale? What a joke.

So yeah, there you go. Furi is a game with a ton of potential and some legitimately thrilling combat systems, all hidden away behind this big veil of mediocrity, tedium, and bad design choices. If you're going to get it, get it on sale. If you want an actually good boss rush game with quality music and fun mechanics, go play Cuphead or Everhood or something.

117413797.review:
[quote]💬 [i]“Excellence is not an art, it's pure habit. We are what we repeatedly do.”

― The Edge[/i][/quote]

[h1][b]🚀 Overview[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[table]
[tr]
[th]👍 Merits[/th]
[th]👎 Flaws[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
✔️ Robust boss-rush experience

✔️ Entrancing bosses

✔️ Solid presentation

✔️ Terrific soundtrack
[/td]
[td]
❌ Needs more lore
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]


[h1][b]🚪 Introduction[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
At first glance, I thought Furi was an anime-like difficult hack and slash experience focusing only on boss-oriented levels with bullet hell sections. Well..., I was right this time. It's short in length, large in width, and intends to spend some quality time with your sanity, concentration, and level of dedication. Prepare yourself for a rough route, and don't let the stylish art style play its magic on your expectations; you are up for a challenge.

[h1][b]🎮 Single-player[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[b]💠 Prison Break[/b]

The jailer is the key, kill him, and you'll be free. It's the Stranger's only way out of the celestial, impassable prison specially built for him and him only. Heh..., imagine that! Anyway, you play as the Stranger, whose main objective is simple: get away and slay anyone standing in the way. Who sets you free at first is a wacky weirdo wearing a fluffy fancy version of the bunny mask from the movie Donnie Darko. He'll be your walking-talking radio, aiding your escape with useless tips (my opinion) and valuable info regarding the story lore, as you both share the same goal. Overall, he's a compelling companion.

[b]💠 Guardians of the Galactic Prison[/b]

They are the jailers standing in the way, the best of the best. Floating in space is the prison with a surreal set of spatial worlds linked by mystical gates. Each world has a unique atmosphere that well defines its jailer's attributes. Each boss is sui generis in character, appearance, and fighting style. I think they deserve more lore and a multilayered depth in the game's character-driven story. The plot is engrossing as the characters are, and the excitement builds up as you progress to unveil the fruit of the tale. It's not the type of story that will lay its cards at ease after the curtain falls; it will require some deep thoughts to reveal its true meaning.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2822121139
[b]💠 Freedom Fighter[/b]

You are a samurai armed with a lightning Katana and a laser pistol. As for the guardians, each has a special weapon that defines their combat style. There are two gameplay modes: duel fighting and walking sections. You go to a segment, defeat its jailer and move on to the next. Each fight has various phases, each consisting of two portions (with some exceptions). First is the usual open arena encounter, where you can move freely and use both weapons to deplete the enemy's shield bar. After the health bar is exposed, you enter a close-range personal duel in which you can drain it using only melee combos. Defensive options are dashing: appropriate for evading bullets; and parrying: more suitable for countering melee strikes. Power attacks range from charging your gunshot, slash, and boost; also, charging your dash increases the evasive range. In summary: the combat is simple, satisfying, and responsive.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2823927307
[b]💠 Furi vs Dark Souls[/b]

While they both focus on difficult bosses, their methods differ. Unlike the slow-paced strategic gameplay in Dark Souls, Furi is a fast-paced game that will punish you for not taking risks; also, it has a small room for errors and reconfiguring your plan while fighting. Don't get me wrong, though; planning a strategy is crucial in Furi, but it has to be after learning your enemy's attack patterns and before going into battle; there is no time to think during a fight. It all hinges on your reflexes, muscle memory, and knowledge of the attack patterns.

There is no weapon variety or any form of upgrades in Furi. You'll always play as the same character you started with regardless of the difficulty mode or the level you're playing. The only upgrade you're getting is you. It will show you your true power of adaptation. You'll be astonished by how drastically your skills can evolve by practicing, making you a grandmaster in Furi, and when that happens, you'll become the boss all the guardians fear. An obvious difference is the bullet hell phases in Furi, where it pushes your concentration and reflexes to the limit. In conclusion: they differ much more than they have in similar.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2821692697
[b]💠 You Can Do It[/b]

As hard as it gets, it will always be fair. Rarely can you blame the game for losing or even getting hit. The levels are well-balanced; they only require gitting gud. But don't let the heat of the challenge push you away. In my first playthrough, I had a D rank with 2000+ hits and 100+ KOs on Furi difficulty. It went from there to an S rank with 158 hits and 0 KOs on Furier difficulty. All it took was some practice. Good news: there is a mode for practicing where you can fight any enemy in any order and access the invincible option, which allows you to focus on different aspects of the fight. It offers becoming invincible, exposing an enemy's health bar, and skipping or locking phases. Another mode is the speedrun, which records your time and hit count, and there are no walking sections while you fight all the bosses in sequence.

[h1][b]🛠️ Technical[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[b]💠 S Rank for the Ep!c Soundtrack[/b]

Each boss has an exclusive soundtrack that not only sets the mood to blend with the atmosphere but somehow manifests the enemy's appearance and evokes his character in the player's imagination, making him see them with his mind before his eyes. In addition, the music's rhythms are well-integrated into the fight phases, inducing a fervor feeling that ups the enthusiasm to 11. Furi's aesthetic utilizes a colorful minimalistic approach with cool particle effects to define its art style. I can't say the same for the mediocre shadow quality that can often reduce the overall visual appeal. More than one executive animation per boss could've added much more to the cinematic aspect of the game.

[b]💠 Controller Highly Recommended?[/b]

Yes. Why? Mainly because you can't get that sweet 360° directional movement with a keyboard, which you'll do a lot, BTW. Sure, you can get that radial movement using a mouse, but it'll follow your aiming direction. As for a gamepad, there are two analogs, one for shooting and the other for movement, so it'll be much easier and more comfortable. Mostly, arenas have a radial design, so you'll be moving in curved directions most of the time, which can get strenuous using WASD buttons. So is it playable on a keyboard and mouse? I've S ranked the game on Furier using only keyboard and mouse. For me, the best layout was to change the reticle mode to radial and the movement mode to reticle, but when I have to dodge and shoot in different directions, I change the movement mode to directional.

[h1][b]⚖️ Verdict[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
It's a brilliant mix of swordplay and bullet hell that never fails to make you hold your breath. It's under an hour of content that will take way more for you to learn each boss, adapting to their patterns as you witness your skills grow; it's an substantial success of showcasing what you can achieve through the sheer force of practice and commitment.

Overall Rating: 9.5/10

This game is amazing. Originally I picked it up for free with PlayStation Plus a long time ago but was very bad at it and couldn't get past the 2nd boss. But after I got it on PC... I still sucked :D

But I kept trying and trying and really got into the rhythm of the game and soon was able to beat it, and I can say that Furi is in my top 5 favorite games of all time list. Thankfully this is one of the games none of my friends who are actually good at games play, so I can happily say I'm the best Furi player in my friend group :)

The combat feels great in this game, I love the chaos of trying to find the right time to hit or shoot an opponent while avoiding their onslaught of attacks. This game also boasts a beautiful soundtrack created by a handful of very good artists, and I find myself listening to these tracks on repeat, even replaying fights with no sound on but the music. The story is a pretty good one, if not a little hard to discover without help from a wiki, but I found it to be decent enough to have me caring about the characters.

I would also like to add that this game recently had DLC added after being out for so many years, which I have not played, but when they released the new DLC they made the old "One More Fight" DLC free, which I find pretty based.

116761897.review:
Furi is a simple game. You play as this cyber, mute samurai dude who has been imprisoned on a floating island in space for eons and now must fight through the wardens guarding your path to reach the earth.

The thing that immediately catches your attention would be the gameplay. The only challenges the game presents are the boss fight with the wardens you will meet along the way to freedom. But beware these bosses are anything but easy.

The game fuses hack and slash with bullet hell elements to create some insane setpieces while also always keeping you moving. Parrying attacks, dodging enemy bullets, weaving through waves of lasers, Furi grasped the basics of being a great action game down to a t. 

Next point to bring up is the music. Furi soundtrack is all funk and rock that helps give a unique atmosphere to the adventure. From the suspenseful buildup when walking towards another warden or the bloodpumping music against the wardens themselves, Furi's soundtrack rarely ever fails to hype you up.

If all your looking for is a game where all you do is fight a series of hardcore bosses back to back then Furi is the right game for you. And if you are looking to replay this game several times, it already has extra modes to help spice up your good time.

8/10

115892199.review:
Honestly, not what I expected. In a way, I can see it being inspired by Afro Samurai... and the mechanics looked really cool from the video! But from my time with Furi, that's really where the good part ends, just mechanics. 

You're tossed into a world with zero clue, which can be a way to make people curious about the world, but it does not provide any opportunity for me as a player to learn more about it. This is a game with little to no world. You wake up, walk to an arena, slay a boss and walk through a door to slay another boss. I don't find there to be any exploration available here. The story doesn't seem to be cohesive either. Your mission is to escape prison and get your freedom, but you have to fight another prisoner to make progress. For some reason, the prison is constructed in such a way that the prisoner obstructs your path to another prison chamber.

I have shared that the mechanics are great, but they do feel a little clunky from my perspective. Changing camera angles (during combat) makes it very odd of an experience, and I suppose it's because it is an aged game. There's also mechanics that prevent you from fully taking advantage of staggering or downing an opponent, by making your opponent invulnerable. 

Right now, it's just a game that looks cool, has a nice idea, does the combat well, but held back by some ideas. Paired with lack of information about the world to keep things interesting, and a lack of cohesion in the story, it just makes it not really that great of a game in my opinion.

115820886.review: A fantastic game made with love and you can feel it in everything. The movement and animations are fluid, the music is bangin', the bosses are challenging but can be mastered, and with the DLC you have even more options. However, if you want an even more fluid experience, get the Onamusha DLC and play the DLC character over the original. One of the only hiccups that I've ever had with the original character is that you can't just tap the dash button to do a fixed range dodge, you have to hold the dash for like half a second before you even do a short dash. This one gripe with the original character made the final boss ultra frustrating for me so I put the game down until more recently when Onamusha launched. The dual forms are not only a lot of fun to get the rhythm down with, but the speed form doesn't require charging the dash. It's a fixed range you can adapt around rather than being forced to wait a half second for the original dash to charge which can lead to getting hit. Outside of that minor gripe with a moderately priced solution, it's a top-tier combat game you should play.

115607186.review:
A simple but amazing game. Furi is a boss rush that switches between bullet hell and swordplay. Story is interesting and the graphics are really simple cel shading. While its simple playstyle and looks may make the game seem thrown together, it is immediately redeemed by its crazy gameplay backed by an adrenaline pumping soundtrack.
The game is pretty hard in its own right. If you've never played a bullet hell game before, then a lot of the sections in this game will seem unreasonably daunting and unfair. However, with that said, I believe that the game does a great job in naturally teaching you how to deal with all of its different projectiles and attacks through color and sound cues. If you enjoy the thrill of learning and adapting against an seemingly impossible enemy; getting pummeled for hours until you improve to the point that you are styling on everyone, then this game is for you.

115324054.review:
Furi is a challenging experience that expects the player to just "git gud". This game focuses on fast-paced boss fights only and each one of them has from 4 to 6 stages. It literally takes every aspect of an action game and merges it all into ten boss fights. From bullet hell to hack and slash, you have it all. The player will make their way through trial and error so expect to feel frustrated. However, it is one of those games that makes you want more; you always come back to it. You start off by dying a lot at the beginning of the fights but you slowly progress to the late stages of the boss. You take a break and then come back because you're just so close to defeating the boss! And once you get it, the cycle starts again.

Story-wise, Furi is about a mysterious man (The Stranger, later Rider) that has been jailed and their mission is to find and kill the jailer. They're the key. As The Stranger walks to the bosses arenas, the player will see vibrant and intriguing surroundings along with someone known as The Voice, who wears a rabbit disguise and acts as the narrator. However, none of these areas are available to interact with. The Stranger only walks forward or backwards, in a linear path.

It is visually stunning, I love its sci-fi setting and the retro/synth soundtrack is amazing. It really puts you in the mood.

Furi's replayability is high. There are three endings and one secret boss fight. The levels are all replayable, if the player is interested in getting a better score.
