This game makes you feel awesome. The soundtrack is such a key part of Furi, and it manages to capture each boss and setting perfectly, at the same time as making the battles feel more intense and honestly just being straight bangers to listen to. The story, whilst simple, is perfect for this type of game, and I think that it's carried out really well, making you feel a range of emotions -  guilt and mystery for me in particular -  and the ending is great, and had a real impact on me as a player when it was revealed. 
As this is a boss rush game, each boss plays a major role, which is awesome because the character designs in Furi are straight fire. Whilst I would've liked to know more about each one, the brief time you spend with them is at least enough for them to be quite interesting. Plus the voice acting and sound design for each is top teir.
However, this will not be a game for everyone. The battles combine a bit of bullet-hell type combat with more melee, pattern-reading and parrying combat. Although this is basically the entire game, the combat stays pretty crisp and enjoyable, and when mastered feels smooth and you feel powerful, although each boss will always be at least slightly threatening. So, if your looking for an intense game and love fighting games or bullet hells, you'll probably love Furi. 
I liked it, and these kind of games aren't usually for me, so yeah. Furi is pretty epic

114550984.review:
At the time of writing this, the "One More Fight" DLC has been unlisted for purchase, which is fine, That's not what this review is about, I'm saying that because once it IS back up, I will revise this review for the DLC.

Let me get the stuff you're here for out of the way, I rate this game a 9.8/10, buy it off sale or on sale, it's worth it either way, the ost is incredible, same with the story. The gameplay is fluid like water and responsive like lightening, couldn't recommend enough.

I've put 28 Hours into Furi, gotten every achievement, completed the story-mode on Furi and Furier difficulty (both later completed with S ranks). I've gotten an S in the speedrun gamemode, and achieved every ending, including secret ones. To say I put in the effort to get the most out of this game would be a understatement.

And after all that, what do I think of the game?

[h1] I Really, Really, REALLY, like, no- LOVE, this game. [/h1]

[SPOILERS AHEAD, KINDA, I RANT ALOT IN THIS BUT THERE ARE STILL A FEW]

I have never replayed a full story based game more than Furi. Putting myself into the shoes of "The Stranger" for the fifth time and exacting sweet, sweet revenge towards those who imprisoned me never loses its initial rush. While the story did seem at times bare-bones through my first playthrough, I realized I was too busy trying not to get sliced, shot, burned, punched, or drugged (looking at you "The Scale") that the deeper elements of the story breezed past my head. I was too on-edge throughout even the basic difficulty, praying that the next guardian I'd fight wouldn't be worse or as bad as the one I just barely survived getting past; only to be wrong, each, and every time. Thankfully, however, the incredible replayability factor this game has provided no other need for an excuse than to just, hit new game again.

Upon my second and third playthrough, it all started to make a little more sense, bit by bit. (This is speculation from what I gathered) The man who frees you, known simply as "The Voice", is a broken man, shrouded in mystery, like the protagonist. The Voice, however, remains on the opposite side of the moral spectrum, for it was The Voice who created the prison you dwell in. Vast, vast planning, years of building, all done by The Voice, in order to keep you locked away, and yet suddenly, you're freed, by him. The Voice dedicated himself to his craft, and as consequence, isolated himself from his daughter, in pursuit of his work. Eventually, he was locked away too, now forever sealed away from her face, her laugh, forever- unless..
The dynamic between The Stranger and The Voice is something I haven't seen done in many videogames, in a way you're both the same, you both need to escape, you need eachother, and yet, the toll weighs heavier on The Voice in the grand scheme of things. The Voice uses you as a last ditch effort at freedom, when all is lost, every other planned failed, The Voice reduces all of his life's work to nothing in order to see his daughter. The Voice bets everything on one ideal, that humanity is worth saving. He knowingly sends out the one thing capable of annihilating Earth to obtain freedom, and bets on his ability to convince The Stranger that Mankind is worth saving. I understood all of this by simply playing the game, I've never searched for Lore on a fan wiki site or anything. When paying attention, the game's story really begins to shine in depth, and puts a new spin onto each action and word said by The Voice. Now like I said, the thought process during my first playthrough was only one thing: "The Jailer is the key, kill him, and you'll be free.", that's because everything else in my head was screaming at me to dodge, run, dash, shoot, and parry my way to survival, because trust me, this game's gameplay IS NOT EASY BUD.

 Of course saying something isn't easy doesn't exclude it from being fun, incredible even. The tight-knit combat of CQC interactions partnered by extravagant bullet hell/laser sections had me yelling in surprise, and  screaming in delight as I laid waste to my foe when delivering a perfect parry or charge slash. Dashing, however, is quite possibly the most intense part of this game, ESPECIALLY ON FURIER. Moments when you must be what feels like mere pixels away, just to barely zip past the object unharmed is satisfying every, single, time. Or when faced with an attack that puts the enemy fully invisible, causing the player to make split second blocks and parries based solely off auditory queues. (Calling out The Burst, huge piece of tresh.) 

Furi is one of the best games I've played in a while, and I can safely say will never be forgotten by me.

Here are some words I'd like to say before I wrap this up

To all those who are still trying to beat The Star on Furier, may God Rest your Soul

The Scale is the worst boss in the game, he's not constructed bad, he's just [b] The worst boss in the game. [/b]
The Edge is my favorite boss, so much in that fight still gives me trouble to this day and I love it.

That's about it, all in all, I recommend this game :)

113869441.review:
[h1]Please… Hold my hand.[/h1]

I should begin by saying that I absolutely adore this game and have played it to death (on a pirated copy). It isn't for everyone, but it certainly is for me.

The game isn't without a couple of flawed design choices, but it exudes so much love and care and thought that it more than compensates for it's few mistakes. There are so many good ideas here, implemented so very neatly. Notably, lore elements tie into gameplay with a subtlety and cohesion few games achieve, from re-spawning all the way to the order in which the guardians are presented to The Stranger. In the end, [spoiler] you are forced to kill The Beat[/spoiler]. 

The soundtrack is a blast, it has never left me since the first time I played through the game; the character design by Takashi Okazaki is simply stunning, the concept art a true delight to stare at wide-eyed; the dialogue is brief and stimulating, filled to the brim with quotable one-liners; and, for my fellow sweaty weebs out there, the japanese dub is pure ear candy. But what's perhaps most important for a game like Furi, it simply feels [i]good[/i] to be The Stranger. Except for the part where [spoiler]you are forced to kill The Beat[/spoiler]. That aside, the moving, the slashing and the shooting all feel amazing.

One of my favorite things about Furi is how shockingly replayable it is. If you beat this game once, you [b]must[/b] play through it [b]at least[/b] once again. The second time through, fuck fugg fuck shit peepee & also caca, it feels [i]so good[/i]. It's like that fabled first nut, if the first nut came second. The reason why it's so good and so shocking is that you'll no doubt be overwhelmingly surprised by how much you've learnt and improved from having faced the challenge of beating the game for the first time.

I also love Bernard as a final challenge, I loved the feeling of achievement I got the first time I finally beat him, and I love the requirement of raw skill, not just pattern recognition, to do so. Worth the effort, fellas.

One of my only complaints (and surely my deepest-felt) about the game is that [spoiler]you are forced to kill The Beat[/spoiler]. Notably fucked up.

Not much more to say for me, I think. Not much said, either. Certainly more of a love letter than anything else. For quality, much less biased reviews of the game, I deeply recommend you watch Joseph Anderson's and Matthewmatosis' reviews on Youtube. 

[spoiler]You are forced to kill The Beat[/spoiler].

113819016.review:
[i]We all have choices to make. We all have to decide what's worth fighting for.[/i]

To say that Furi is one of my favorite games is simply an understatement. It's fully cemented itself in my mind for the past year now, as I've recently come back to beat it the full way through on normal difficulty.

There really is so many strong suits this game comes on with. A game just about boss fights? Sounds like it'd be pretty hellish and would keep beating you down, but the game finds a way to keep urging you forward to get the next piece of the puzzle, a bit more of the plot. And at the end it all comes together perfectly to an amazing ending that I'll never soon forget. Amazing story, amazing boss designs and fights, and above all else some of the best video game music I've ever heard, hands down.

If you don't mind struggling a bit for a game that rewards you a tenfold for doing so, please try Furi. This game is the golden example of why I play video games.

113307035.review:
Some reviews are hard to do, some reviews are easy to do, and some reviews require care because you are handling porcelain ideas. This is of the last category. The Game Bakers have put one hundred percent into Furi, and its magnificence reflects this. If you have ever touched a combat game, especially of the boss rush variety, you must play this.
Furi's soul is simple: you are a Stranger, a silent prisoner in a weird scifi jail being held for an unknown crime, and you want to no longer be in jail. Several people object. Armed with a sword, a two-firing-mode gun, body armor, fighting skill, and the wisdom of a mysterious rabbit man - without even SHOES - you must overcome: the jailer is the key; kill him, and you'll be free. Without wading into spoilers, suffice it to say escaping a prison can represent quite a journey. Some of your foes hate you. Some of them will be hated back. The story is sparingly told, with inference and visuals doing a lot of the talking: the Stranger sees a new jailer and instantly shoots him, a jailer completes a personal ritual before facing the prisoner, the rabbitty companion recounts an opponent's crimes in a hiss. Eventually the question goes from "how do I escape?" to "what does my escape mean, exactly?" What it means, in short, is Something Memorable.
Your goal: survive a run-on of high tension hack-slash-shoot encounters, HOPEFULLY with a controller on hand. Usually these will have not only multiple stages but multiple phases as well: boss loses the first blue health bar after dodging missiles and trading blows and pistol firing, then a red one pops up underneath and you’re drawn into a close range melee-only affair. Behavioral rules get laid down for the most part in your very first fight - you can parry about half of what gets thrown at you, flailing out of turn will goad the boss into breaking pattern and painfully countering you, green shots yield health when attacked, and so on. When you fall, you’re not dead; each fight gives you several “retry” health bars as well, and passing a stage will refill a retry if one’s used up. Technically, it means that canny gamers can make a few terrible fumbles and still get through a stage on the first shot. This doesn’t convey the speed of the action, though; even the normal difficulty tutorial is something like shootshootgrabfacewhackwhackelectrocutionbigpulsefaildodgedead. It’s punishing and relentless and fun and the sort of challenge that makes you slam the table and snarl “YOU WILL NOT BEAT ME” through your teeth, and when you win against the first foe you’ll feel like ripping your shirt in half with a rebel yell and wrestling a bear into submission. Most enemies have quirks, like arena obstacles or unique responses to certain moves. Every one of them is showy and resilient and is basically an atomic bomb with legs. It’s not terribly easy the first time, and when you unlock Furier difficulty you’ll suddenly realize it’s throwing attack variants and double lasers and why does the Scale’s basic close-range combo now do an area-of-effect discharge? Despite all that, if you’re willing to stick with it, it’s got the primal beat-the-end-boss high essentially constant through the entire game. It’s hard, but it’s also worth it.
The game’s production stands on the peak of Olympus. Visually, it’s a standup showing how to do less with more. Much of the design comes courtesy of Takashi Okazaki, whose art brought us some child-unfriendly-but-tremendously-auteur work. Everything is abstract or simplified in texturing, but from the environments to the characters it’s still got “I recognize that t-shirt” down pat. Old meditation dude with headphones and a modified clock hand greatsword? Check. Weird repetition of U- and equals-shapes across many models’ and locations’ motifs? Check. Vast machines of obvious power and opaque purpose? Check. Man who will beat you to a pulp with an oar? Regrettably, check. This one stands out from the crowd. It’s complimented by a functionally well-designed soundscape. You don’t know what that hat lady does when you meet her, but when you mistime an attack and she counters you’ll recognize that sour nauseous ring immediately. Melee techniques which you can parry to regain health have a weirdly satisfying mechanical wheeee to them, and a metallic rattle precedes the big fanning attacks that you need to entirely avoid. After you get through enough enemy projectiles that can’t be shot down you’ll realize they have a distinct pop when fired. It means you can face a boss the first time and sight-read (hearing-listen?) many behaviors, though dealing with them is trickier. Similarly, the voice acting is above par, though for some it might get a tad distracting after a while; it’s not quite so impressive until you see how many different languages they put together for their roster. Some characters land on bland, but others sell you utterly - “Finally!! …… Revenge.” says one guy’s words, and the delivery is chilling. If you cut Furi, it will bleed style.
The music, now, that’s an echelon above merely “outstanding.” The music’s one for the ages. The developer decided that they wanted to invest in this project, and so they picked up a whole squad of electro-techno geniuses to do the score. Names like Lorn, Scattle, Danger, Carpenter Brut. There are no bad songs in this soundtrack and to be frank the game’s worth buying on the music’s strength alone, and every artist who contributed is worth searching up and giving a listen in their own right. The throb of the beat turns the feel of a loss from frustration to psychotic persistence - because you may have gotten your head handed to you, but listen to that baseline and try to convince yourself to not get up and give it another shot and you will most certainly fail. Full disclosure, the author’s had moderate interest in game soundtracks in the past but Furi lit a fire for looking at them as art in their own right. If you get the game then absolutely grab the tunes as well.
Some faults. If you look elsewhere you’ll probably hear about how the walking outside of combat is bleh, and yes, that’s somehow so awkward they added an automatic walking feature. It’s… baffling. The movement and responsiveness and action has an animal joy to it when you’re fighting but if the Stranger walks over an angled curb his whole body tips back like a drinking bird toy. There are also a couple times where the camera is less a help than a hindrance due to the fixed angle; more angles, please! Perhaps the biggest complaint is not a defect, but rather how much is left unsaid by the plot’s reveals. There’s a few thousand tons of interesting backstory that doesn’t get a moment in the spotlight, and though most of the big questions get answered by the final curtain call, it still leaves something to be desired.
Ultimately, Furi is an animal that has been streamlined and crossbred to exactly one purpose, and that is delivering a gameplay experience whose quality makes it one of the author’s favorite games of all time. Your vision gets tinted a little golden when you encounter the good times and upbeat story elements. It gets dashingly dark when you start to see the whole picture and start to fight for something in addition to simple love of the game. It gets a euphoric halo when you finally beat a boss after twenty consecutive failures and fist pump hard enough to wrench something. For the sheer number of hours spent contemplating the game divided by number of hours played, it has proven itself unique in the author’s library. Maybe don’t jump right in if you don’t care for fighting games or hard games, but to be honest… if you ever have to take a chance on not liking a title, Furi’s uncommonly worth the gamble.

112069397.review:
It's an all-bosses action game that alternates between bullet hell and close combat. It has a great art style, smooth and satisfying looking animations, an interesting yet mysterious story, and a fantastic soundtrack. The only downside is that a controller is practically required as the keyboard/mouse controls are kind of janky. 

Once you beat the game, you unlock Furier, the harder difficulty. This isn't just a "you take more damage and deal less damage" type of thing, everything is the same except for the bosses' moves. For the most part, these bosses are only slightly different in Furier difficulty, but you will soon find that these slight differences make a big change in terms of difficulty. Some are relatively easy to adjust to, others force you to adapt strategies you wouldn't normally use, or hadn't thought of, in the normal difficulty.

As far as achievements go, I got most of them unintentionally and only had to go out of my way for a few of them, and a handful of them are just hidden cutscenes or different endings, so they're relatively easy to get with a spoiler free achievement guide.

Overall I recommend this to anyone who's searching for a challenge or loves bullet hell, because this game has a lot of that.

The music is what initially reeled me into this game, and because I previously played Sekiro and was enjoying myself with difficult boss fights this game seemed right up my alley.

[u]Why I love this game:[/u]
The visuals are unique and very atmospheric, the music adds to the atmosphere massively, it feels like the game is a hidden gem in terms of music, because [b]I am in love with this soundtrack.[/b] The characters for the most part are written well and the challenging gameplay feels very rewarding when making progress, the game is a lot about learning and improving on previous mistakes.

[u]Gameplay:[/u]
It has elements of a souls-like, but the choice of camera and amount of projectiles certainly keeps the game closer to a bullet hell type game. As a person that doesn't generally enjoy bullet hell too much I was still having fun in all of the fights except for the last, which leaned too heavily into bullet hell, while the visuals made it hard to tell how and where to avoid projectiles. 

Other than the very final fight, which also stretched on for too long when having to reset, the game itself is incredible, the game and story has me hooked all the way through.

110119111.review:
This game is nothing but tight, satisfying boss fights with clear mechanics--even the most annoying one was still better than a lot of the bosses you'll fight in much bigger games. The more you understand the little details of how your moves can interact with the boss's, the more you'll be rewarded by finding clever counters and weak points that aren't obvious.

Big warning, though (no spoilers): there is an optional final boss depending on your choices that is so long, tedious and boring that it almost made me not recommend this game--it really brings down the overall quality of the game compared to all the incredibly fun previous fights. I did eventually beat it but it took about a third of my entire playtime of the game to finally get past it. I personally feel like it's one of the least enjoyable bosses I've ever fought in any game, so think about how good the rest of the game has to be to make me still recommend it!

Beyond the gameplay, you can look at any of the art or trailers to see it's just dripping with visual style, with a killer soundtrack and excellent voice work to match. If you have the patience for the last boss, this'll be one of the best games in your collection easily.

109871462.review:
Furi is one of my favourite games I've played in the last year. Strongly recommend to anybody with a controller.
PROS
- Banging soundtrack. Carpenter Brut, Scattle and Kn1ght are at the absolute top of their game here. You're Mine is an absolute masterpiece.
- Great gameplay. Mix of Touhou bullet hell, and hack and slash. Great stuff, goes together suprisingly well.
- Story is out of the way, but abstract enough to let you think about it.
- Cheap. £4 on sale. Do it.

CONS
- Cameras a bit iffy at times, especially if you happen to be at the top of the arenas. Minor issue.
- Some bosses last phases are pretty wild. Challenging.
- The game has the No More Heroes structure of a bunch of distinct bossfights, but the down time is spent walking. A little lame, but I get it. Just press A and you automatically walk to the next bossfight. Its interesting to see the enviroment but it could have been done in a more interesting way.

TL:DR
PLAY FURI IF YOU MEET ONE OF THE FOLLOWING CRITERIA
- Enjoy hack and slash games (Like Metal Gear Rising)
- Enjoy games where you feel yourself getting better (or Soulslikes)
- Enjoy music from the artists on the soundtrack
- Enjoy very replayable but shorter games

The DLC is okay. 2 more bossfights. Get if you enjoy the main game. If you choose the Confirm ending you are a weak coward.

Storywise, you'll get to know the lore of the bosses through a NPC which basically is your companion throughout the game. Some of the bosses are more talkative than others, which adds flavor to their character. The game is challenging, but bosses are defeatable. As for cons, the "walk" to the next boss is kind of restricted and bland with the only good thing being the NPCs monologue and soundtrack. There is also no items, but I think that is intentional. All in all, a solid 8/10.

109167582.review:
For a whole week I did not have any internet connection at my house, and the only game I had downloaded was this, and what a rush of an experience that was, Furi is such a demanding yet rewarding and satisfying game, easily the hardest one I've ever been able to beat, yet everything about its responsive and fast-paced gameplay, stunning art direction and dialogue I simply couldn't get enough of.

It's a game that pushes you to your limits and you come out stronger thanks to it, it'll taunt you, hit you while you're down and pose yet another impossible challenge before you every time you overcome one. Yet it's never unfair, wether you win or lose a battle depends entirely on your skill, which the game will make sure you can naturally aquire. Both the bullet hell and the hand to hand combat sections of every boss fight is so carefully and satisfyingly designed that by the end of it you'll become so unstoppable it'll leave you wanting a bigger challenge (of which there'll be plenty to test your strength).

Not only does it have possibly the most addicting combat I've experienced, but it's also full of interesting ideas, amazing and memorable characters both in personality and in design, an intricate story full of twists and thoughtful questions, and that's not even to mention what might legitimately be one of the best videogame OSTs of all time, seriously, some of its songs may actually be more popular than the game itself, they're THAT good.

I've beat this game about 10 times purely because it was fun to, it's the first game i've ever wanted to replay and beat on a higher difficulty and the first game to push me into getting the highest score on the highest difficulty. Perhaps it may be too hard for some people, and that's ok, but if you want a challenge, Furi will give you all the tools you need to overcome yourself. (at a game that is). Definitely one of my favorite titles of all time.

On a scale of 1 to 10, this game is an 11. And it would give itself a 12. 

Furi begs you to be consumed by its colour and sound and become pure instinct. There are no distractions in Fury. There is you, your path, and the opponents who stand in your way. Everything they do to stop you in your tracks you can learn to predict. From the moment you learn an opponents moves, it is for your sword arm to follow through.

It is a difficult game, but it is also a game that knows how to teach you. Each fight is a puzzle, and there's nothing quite like the joy of figuring out for yourself (with the help of the games excellent feedback) the strategies that will allow you to win. The simplicity of the design makes the games language easy to learn, whilst not detracting in any way from the beauty of the art. It makes up for it in style one hundred times.

Support your indie market buy buying this amazing little gem of a game.

107769379.review:
As someone who enjoys games like Cuphead, the DMC franchise and souls-like games, I could not enjoy this one. The artwork is very stylish and pretty to look at though. The gameplay itself felt like a chore. 

There's little room to improvise strategies and the bosses (assuming this is just a boss rush mixed with bullet hell game) sometimes feel overpowered. Knock the boss down, they get iframes. Attack them as they're charging up an attack? They can dodge and attack you. Didn't get a parry in the fraction of a second? Be ready for your punishment. Had to use a continue? You'll get your full health back...so does the boss and they already had more to begin with. Boss performing super powerful attacks? Can't hit them til they're done. Mind you, this last longer than you would expect. The first boss acts more of a tutorial but plays pretty cool. After that, be ready for long drawn out battles unless you're just really, really good at this game.

The story could've made the tedious fights worth it but I have no clue what the story is. Maybe if I beat the game I would find out but that's just bad story-telling. The jailer is the key. Kill him and you're free. That's all I know and that's from the store page. Your companion (or jailer for all I know) is telling you some things but it's not cohesive or engaging. People with powers get locked up and something or other. I get that the point of the game is more boss rush than story. So is Cuphead and that game establishes the story early on and sprinkles details as you go along. It still focuses on boss fights but we know why Cuphead and Mugman are collecting deeds for the Devil. Why is this guy trying to get free? Yes, yes, he's locked up in prison but most people want to be free if locked up. What makes his case so special? I don't know. I guess if I finish the game...

Then there is the bloody auto-walk feature! Why does this exist?! Just press a button and the character will mosey on over to the next boss. I'm assuming this acts as a transition scene. You can move the character yourself between boss fights but there is no exploration or npcs. There are no collectibles. There are no alternate paths. The guy just walks in one direction while your companion (?) talks to you. Cutscenes would be much better than having the character move at a snail's pace to the next boss. He doesn't run. Guess he has to save that spectacular energy for a boss fight? Don't know. Not explained in the story.

I know this game got a lot of positive reviews and I might get flack but I don't care. Again, I enjoy games like Cuphead, DMC, Salt & Sanctuary, Celeste and even Ikaruga! I wanted to like this game but I was largely underwhelmed.

107526839.review:
[h1]NO, FURI IS NOT GOOD[/h1] 

[b]The idea on paper seems great, but the execution is poor, mediocre. [/b]

Furi is akin like action hack and slash of Nier Automata, with shooting and bullet time element dispersed in it. But unlike Nier, which controls fluidly, Furi controls terribly. Furi is not the organic action game like how some reviewers here make it to be, it is very much a scissors paper stone game. 

[b]MECHANICS: 4/10 [/b]
Unlike DMC or Nier where you can learn and react accordingly or with multiple approach, in Furi when boss throws a rock, you must throw paper. You can't just slash boss when you are near, they will teleport away instantly and have instant block or instant counter, so you must wait till they finish all their special movements and there is a small moment where you can slip in an attack. When they are throwing bullet time at you, it's all dodging till they finish. Unfortunately, the controls are also not sharp, dodging has a very slight delay that makes you miss most dodges, it's just not as instant as Nier or DMC, imagine there's a half sec delay each time you press dodge. So dodging consecutively is impossible here, you either know exactly the pattern when to dodge, or you will get hit when they throw consecutive range attacks. 

They have a parry system, but also unfortunately, there is no cancel input, so if you press parry twice and decide to dodge, you will have to parry twice first. Then, the parry timing is EXTREMELY tight, tighter than Sekiro, but if you miss the timing, you don't go into a block like Sekiro, you get hit instantly. They have a perfect parry, where you parry at the very last second and get a counter, but you won't be able to execute this consistently at all, because it all depends on luck, you only have 0.5 sec to react, whether you get that 0.1 sec it's all luck.

The 4th samurai boss is a great example of this, it is a forced close combat, where you must parry and CANNOT dodge. You memorize must his parry pattern, or you will never pass this boss ever. The moment your parry finishes, you must immediately press attack, if you accidentally press another parry, you will miss your chance. No button mash, one press for every attack. 

So in reality it doesn't matter how fast you are, it's all about memorization and scissors paper stone. Because no matter how fast you are, when it's time for the boss to attack, you can only dodge/parry.

[b]STORY: 2/10[/b] 
While I understand this is low budget game, there is no reason not to put some effort into decent writing. It's basically all nonsensical talk spoken in 10 different ways. After every battle, your companion will talk a bit about the story, but it adds nothing at all, it keeps on saying how you have to escape. Instead of perhaps elaborating the backstory of the next boss you fight, he keeps on spewing the same nonsense over and over again, what a waste of words. 

The way they handle cut-scene is also terrible. They let you press walk in 1 but it's all 1 direction, and you can press 1 button and let him walk automatically, but the camera is static all the way, you really just watch him walk from one end to another in a static camera, this is such a poor cinematography, one of the worst I've ever seen. They spent all this time to build some of the environment aesthetics and they can't even put in the effort to make a moving and slightly more cinematic shots. They could strip away all the walking and just put in camera cuts to let the story play, but they rather let you watch someone walk. 

Cinematography students would have been given an F for this kind of execution. 

SUMMARY: There's a reason this game never took off despite all the good reviews, because it's not good, terrible mechanics, and even worse story. I bought this for about $4 during sale, so I don't feel too bad. But if you have $10 to spare, spend it on Hollow Knight or save it up for DMC 5. 

 [h1]Additional edits: [/h1]
Didn't realize there's so many incels defending this game. To potential buyers reading, just look at the most helpful review here by Winter Wombat, in short:

"It wasn't about thinking on my feet anymore, but memorizing patterns and making zero mistakes. I'd encounter larger and larger stretches were the "difficulty" of a stage came from the increasing amounts of time I'd have to go without tripping up." 

This is what Furi is about, memorization. Then look at their comments: incels insult him for playing for TOO SHORT, so he must not know anything about the game. Then look again at the comments here, saying i took "TOO LONG, so I must suck" even if I beat the game. Judge for yourself who is more honest, but at least I'm helping you save your money & time.

Furi has become one of my favorite games of all time and I highly recommend it to anyone why likes mastering combat mechanics.

This game appealed to me personally in so many ways.

[u]Soundtrack:[/u]
Each boss has their own set of tracks and they are so well suited that I still haven't gotten tired of them 50 hours later. Wonderful work by Carpenter Brut, Waveshaper, Danger, The Toxic Avenger, Lorn, Scattle, and Kn1ght.

[u]Visual Design:[/u]
When I first saw Furi, my love of Metal Gear Solid prompted me to find out more. The character designs are clearly inspired by Yoji Shinkawa's art but brought to life in vibrant 3D locations. I just love to look at it.

[u]Easy Time Commitment:[/u]
When I first picked up Furi, I was not very good at it. I really struggled to make progress at first since I never played games with similar mechanics. The fact that I could spend 20 mins attempting to beat a boss, go do something else, then boot up the game and instantly be at the boss, really kept my frustration in check.

Overall, it is just fun to play. Parrying feels satisfying and once you get comfortable with shoot, slash, dash, and parry in your first playthrough, you get to prove your mastery on Furier difficulty and the One More Fight DLC.

107221224.review:
Ten satisfying boss battles in a stylized anime neon dreamworld, in a neat hybrid fighting system: shoot/slash/dash/parry against a wide variety of attacks, with an emphasis on timing and pattern recognition. The game knows exactly what it wants to be, and a sense of creative commitment shines through — just what you want from an indie. Despite not being to my usual taste, I was compelled by it and committed to seeing it through to the end.

Well, it ended up taking me much much longer than it was supposed to, and stirred up a lot of frustration and annoyance on the way there. Your mileage will vary with your skill level at this kind of gameplay. On scale of 0 to 10, I think I'm probably about a 4. That apparently put me into an awkward gap between "clearly need to switch to easy mode," and "able to make steady progress," and the game didn't know what to do with me.

With most of the bosses I did in fact make steady progress, and had a lot of fun. The ones that drove me crazy were the ones with six stages. They demand that you play perfectly through ten minutes (!) of fighting just to earn the right to spend 20 seconds trying to figure out the nasty bullet hell pattern in the final stage. "Nope, that approach didn't work: play flawlessly for ten more minutes so that you can try something else."

More than once, after sinking hours into some sixth-stage roadblock, I resorted to watching playthrough videos on YouTube, to see if I was being clueless or lacked some kind of essential skill. Nope! I was approaching everything exactly right, and my overall accuracy seemed not much worse than the players in the videos. I was just not QUITE making it... over, and over, and over, and over. "Git gud," I know, I know, but that's exactly what I was doing. Isn't the game supposed to make it rewarding to work on gitting gud?

It ALMOST does. Furi is really really close to hitting the "hard game" sweet spot, of being thrillingly-unforgiving-but-secretly-forgiving. It's intensely demanding, but once you learn its rhythms, the demands turn out to be more than fair — generous, even. Care has clearly been taken with exactly the issue of frustration balancing. I admired and appreciated that. It's why I kept going back for more, and why I'm giving this a thumbs up and calling it "satisfying." It was. 

But it also wasted a lot of my time and pissed me off. It's both at once. Fair warning.

107032510.review: Furi, AKA Touhou Gear Rising: Revengeance is a boss rush game. The campaign consists of walking through a very pretty environment while the rabbit man force feeds you vague exposition, a multi-phased boss fight, then repeat. Do this 9 times and then the credits roll. Then you unlock a speedrun mode that cuts out all the story and a practice mode where you can play specific bosses. [spoiler]There may or may not be an optional 10th boss and hidden 11th boss.[/spoiler] Boss fights are composed of ranged phases, CQC phases, and desperation phases. Ranged phases consist of the boss prancing around their arena while you chase after them to shoot and stab them. In CQC phases your ranged attacks are disabled but the boss is trapped inside your circle of spankings and left to the mercy of your ability to parry. Desperation phases have the boss turn invulnerable and unleash bullet hell only to drop their spaghetti in the end. All the bosses pull from the same bag of tricks but the way they utilize them is pretty varied. There's a hard mode if you enjoy being hurt as much as you enjoy dealing hurt. The soundtrack is dope but I can't speak to the quality of the Steam release since I bought it on Bandcamp. I have no real complaints about the game outside of how the dodge dash can be charged, and thus only activates after you let go of the dodge button instead of immediately when you press it which makes my butt hurt on certain fast boss attacks. Besides that it's pretty solid. 11/10 but not quite a 12. Protip: you can parry projectiles.

Normally I don´t write honest reviews for games but I just felt like doing one for this game.

First of all: I can see why people like this game, it has some parts that could be enjoyed by some players.

Gameplay: the gameplay of this game looks cool and all, but in my opinion it doesn´t feel as good. Usually I´m a fan of Bullet-Hell elements in games but I really dont like how it got implemented in this game. Fighting with the sword was more fun to me, especially when you switch the combat style to the style where you are closer to the enemy (when the ring around the enemy appears, idk how to explain it). Another thing I didn´t like, was how the phase of the boss replenishes all of his health when you lose a life, I get that it´s supposed to be challanging, but at a certain point it just got annoying and frustrating. The last thing I wanted to mention is, that every boss has at least one phase (except for the edge boss fight, i really liked that one) that just doesn´t feel good to fight against. Especially the final boss since that fight is only shooting and bullet hell (the two things I like about the gameplay the least).

Visuals: I know that it´s a game from 2016 so I can look over some things, but in some shots in some cutscenes, you can see for example how the sword of the main character goes through his cape. I know that sounds kinda nitpicky but it just kinda ruined it for me. That also isn´t the only thing that clips through other objects. (other examples are: the hair of the main character and the bridge segments in the 2nd area). Besides that I really don´t have a problem with the visuals and I actually like the different character designs. Oh, and I liked the cutscenes in the fights, when you parry.

Other things: The one thing I enjoyed 100% was the music. I still listen to the soundtrack on spotify so yea, I really like it. I really liked the voice acting too. 

in general: I personally didn´t enjoy the game, but I can see why the game is so popular as it is. So don´t take this review like: "You shouldn´t play this game at all." It´s just not for everyone.

106358597.review:
Such a great bullet hell/Hack n slash!
The story revolves around the Rider and his journey to kill all the jailers that have locked him up and have tortured him endlessly. The characters in this game are quite mystical and not much is known about them, but i think this work in the games favour as it allows the player to come up with their own ideas as to who these individuals are and what their past may have entailed. I really love the Voice as he gives you snippets of information regarding your goal and his as well as giving you vague information of the enemies that you will encounter  and speaking in somewhat of a riddle form from time to time. The story itself is simple enough, but is great in the fact that it both moves the game along pretty well and gives some room for the player to interpret the events that happen in the game. 
The settings that you come across are incredible as each section takes place in some ethereal land and holds a lot of mystery in itself, while also adds to the enemies themselves as an extension of their character. From a swamp ridden abandoned city, to the open, vibrant landscapes, this game gives a lot of variety for the player to look at and also keeps things consistently fresh instead of have a stale setting that could dull the experience. 
Visually, its quite impressive. One thing i really want to highlight is the design of the characters themselves as they all look gorgeous and intriguing in their own way. Not once did i think that they ever looked boring or weren't that nice to look at. In fact i love how they all have a distinct style to them that matches the environments that they reside in. Graphically, its pretty good as while it may not be the most realistic visuals that i have seen, the art style manages to carry the whole look of it making it somewhat ageless and could still rival games of today with its own unique look. 
The Sound and Audio are fantastic with the soundtrack feeling like an electronic odyssey that in itself carries its own mysterious vibe which integrates well with each segment of the game. The audio is very satisfying as each swing of a blade, shot from a gun or attack of an enemy attack just fits perfectly which the overall theme of the game. 
In terms of Gameplay, its both challenging and satisfying to play. The main thing you will be doing in this game is fighting bosses which removes any filler that the game could have had if it were laced with standard enemies and makes it more of a consistent experience. You have loads of moves in this game such as as swinging your katana, shooting your pistol with either weak or strong attacks, a dash mechanic (which you will be using a lot) and a parry which both heals you and deflects enemy attacks. While it may seem like there isn't a lot of moves to perform, the game balances this out with the enemies and their attacks as each one has their own approach as to defeating it and prevents the game from being repetitive. One thing i really like is how some of the projectiles that the enemies fire have their own unique way to counter them. Some you can shoot to get rid of them, some you can parry, some where you simply just have to dodge them and some where if you shoot them, can grant you health. I really like how the fazes of the enemies really do both differ from the last but doesn't stride away from their main way of combat which is nice. The final thing i would like to mention is the healing as if you being a faze of an enemy, if you are missing a life it can grant you another after beating one of its waves which is really good. Not only that, it fully heals you after a section which i think is really fair. 
Overall, Furi is a amazing, consistent action, bullet hell game and i would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a futuristic challenge or a world that holds many secrets within itself.

105263745.review:
If you like flashy combat and positioning as much as I do (and visual and AUDIO presentation on top of it), you 'd say the same thing: this is the best game in existance. 

For starters, Furi has a really solid core combat. Attacking, shooting, dodging, blocking, parrying - every aspect is well thought out and works together beatifully. Sure you don't have crazy combos, but every tool you have is designed in a clever and meaningful way. For instance, you can finish your combo and knock down an enemy only if you perfectly beat an enemy attack. If you hesitated, or made a mistake, you won't be given an opportunity to do a full combo and a boss will start evading and blocking your last attacks. Then as a reward you have enough time to charge your next attack. Brilliant. Then bosses have parries so you can't always rely on memorization even in most straight-forward attack sequences. Another brilliant mechanic.

Developers mention DMC and Platinum titles in the credits and while I love games like Devil may cry or Metal Gear Rising, or Nioh, etc - all of those are great games - among my favorites, but in my opinion the student has long surpassed the teacher, and those games lack some things here or there compared to Furi. Not enough stress on positioning (those games are mostly about timings, Nioh (2) being most position heavy among such games), or some mechanics or design philosophies in those game break the tension of combat, like how in DMC being in air is so safe, you tempt to never use aerial moves at all. Or absence of a real INTENSE challenge on higher levels (increasing hp of enemies so they become walking tanks cerainly ups the difficulty, but it's not the difficulty I'm looking for). Or not realized enough core combat, making a game too difficult and not difficult enought at the same tine.

Furi makes this right. It focuses on INTENSITY of the combat (this is where Furier difficulty shines becoming the epitome of combat intensity) rather than just upping bosses' hp and damage, playing around it's core combat to extreme. And at the same time it stays really forgiving - developers could easily strip you from the ability to regain life after you complete a phase, but they didn't. They didn't take away your heal through block either. Unlike games like Nioh that like to throw oneshots at you, punishing you for every little mistake you make, Furi gives you a lot of space to make mistakes while staying extremely difficult. This is really brilliant design. 
Speaking of intensity, attack and projectile patterns are so inventive (and they become even more elaborate on Furier difficulty) that they create level design by themselves. Each attack shifts arena so much that you forget that you sometimes fight on a round arena.
I don't like bullet hell in many other games where you just need to hover through horde of small projectiles. In Furi each projectile type requires different answer and when combined they always keep you on your toes, constantly making your switch between tasks in your head. This is where dash mechanic comes in with a lot of depth and decision making behind it. It's always thrilling when you stop amongst the chaos on the screen charging your dash to fly through the broadest wave sent at you.  

Lastly I want to mention the presentation and that a lot of moments are truly enhanced through the right choice music as well as voice acting giving us really memorable moments and experience in general.
12/10

105042722.review:
Overall score: 8/10
Credits time: ~4 hours
Speedrun time: 1:01
Achievements: 31/33

I don't usually write *actual* reviews, but this game deserves it.
This review will be segmented.

Gameplay: 9.5/10
Furi tackles combat spectacularly. It introduces the basics to you, such as what buttons to press and when to perform them. What it doesn't teach you outright, you get to learn the good ol' fashioned way: experience. Certain bosses present a spectacularly harder difficulty than others, and yet, not so difficult that you can't complete them after 5-10 minutes of failure (at least Furi mode). This game doesn't beat around the bush when it comes to bullet hell segments. While they might not be particularly long, about every other boss has a section with it towards the end. Even then, it's on the simpler side of bullet hell, so it is not exactly infuriating. What was initially infuriating were the "walking-simulator" sections that most poor reviews attack. While the sections are unskippable and some are rather long, I enjoyed the narrator's lines enough that I quickly forgot I was even in these sections. I learned to embrace them instead of hate them, as I got to see the graphics that were designed for the game as well. As I will touch on later, the dialogue even offered a new perspective upon the second reading. At my third time through the story to grab another achievement, I did get a little bored watching them, however. If they were skippable, I would rate gameplay at 10/10.

Graphics: 7/10
For an indie game, I believe that the graphics were done quite well. At first, the blocky edges were a bit hard to look past, but after playing the game for a couple hours, it's an acquired taste. The colors pop brilliantly, unfortunately a bit too brilliantly at times, as I felt a bit of discomfort in my eyesight during a couple sections of bullet hell.

Story: 8/10
Dang, did not expect this kind of story from a bosh rush game. As to not leave spoilers, I will say that it is simple yet refined. For those that have played the game or are looking to purchase it, please play the storyline through again, even if just in Furi mode again. The narrator throughout the story makes several remarks that hint to a greater story underneath, and it adds complexity to each of the characters presented. There are even 2 endings as well as a secret ending sprinkled within the story. While some basic tropes were present, they were important nonetheless.

Sound Design:
I had to give this it's own category. The voiced dialogue of characters [English] was phenomenal, the lines were delivered excellently and it really made me invested in some of the characters. Not only that, the sound design within combat is great too. Sword slashing sounds right, lasers sound simple like they should be, nothing ever felt out of place. 9/10

Overall:
The achievements were fun to collect as well, really brought out the more minute details within the game. Props to the devs for creating a great game, I could easily sink WAY more hours into it to complete the last two achievements, but I'm gonna take a break for now. I attempted Furier mode and got rather frustrated with my failings on the *first* boss. I was rather impressed with how much more difficult Furier mode was, I'll have to return to it another day. Getting this off my chest: this game definitely does not deserve an M rating. While there is combat and one particular cutscene within combat that's pretty gruesome (The Scale's fight where he impales you), it's no worse than the likes of movies like Black Panther (yet it is only rated PG-13). As for language, there's one instance of the F word but that's kind of hard to avoid anywhere on the internet these days. I suppose if you fail the fight, you would hear it again, or if you quit to the menu it would also present that dialogue yet again, but that particular fight was rather simple and I only heard it used once. I think the Teen rating would fit it better in today's circumstances.

105041265.review:
When i first got furi i expected it to just be a fast paced action game with cool bosses, and it is that. But it's also a game with an interesting and complex story.  You play as the stranger and are captured in a prison to stop the destruction of the world. Naturally you want to escape, so you try everything in your power to do so. 105033833.review:
Okay, so I'm not a player often drawn to the bullet-hell genre of gaming, and as such don't feel super qualified to comment or contrast on Furi's usage of the mechanic, but that opinion ultimately comes from feeling like the chaos of gameplay overrides the satisfaction you get from playing through it; that said, whether it was the fact that only parts of the combat are bullet-hell sequences, that the game designed them well enough to navigate without it feeling confusing or unfair, or both, I didn't feel choked by the feature here. The figurative bullets come out quick, but so is your character, and the game color codes each of them so you have an advantage through that familiarity.

What did draw me to the game was the idea that this game looked like a satisfyingly, stylistic challenge, of which I am drawn to in gaming; deriving satisfaction from souls, and souls-likes, and that inspiring urge to rise to them. Furi effectively being a boss rush meant that I felt that particular sense of fun would be there and wasn't too disappointed in that regard.

All in all the game is fast-paced and requires some quick timing and reflexes to overcome, and I think most of the time a player is able to adjust to the pace of a game when it's consistent, but if you feel like you've struggled to adapt to a faster-pace in the past, the game may not be your speed, literally and figuratively lol.

What was more of a surprise was Furi's story. I never really thought much about it having one in all the time I'd peeked at it from the corner of my eye, but reading some of the steam reviews just before my purchase confirmed it did have one; seemed like it was well-liked, but no one gave any specifics, so I figured I'd shed a little more light on it without revealing spoilers, because it did more for my enjoyment of the game than what I expected, and might also encourage someone else who enjoys that side to play it as well.

First and foremost this game's story is simple and subtle in its delivery, pretty much all of what you discover about it is through the snippets of dialogue from the game's characters, and lightly sprinkled in the environments you're auto-walking through between each boss fight. Overall pretty standard for a game with its core being combat, but the interesting part is the mystery surrounding your silent character; how he ended up where you start the game and why all of the other characters you encounter interact with you the way they do as move forward. 

My expectation was that the bosses were going to be fun to fight and look at while doing so, but didn't realize they'd go beyond that, which they do; now again, the game moves quickly for the most part and these interactions do as well, but most do well to add to the airs of intrigue and mystery about you and them, as they think and feel a bit more than you might've anticipated for AI bosses in that slash, slash, pew, pew game you bought lol.

The big reveal and answers to some of the glaring questions happens specifically AFTER the credits, so be sure to stick around til' then, but again the same applies as before, it isn't some brilliant sight of all these puzzle pieces clicking together, the revelation comes quickly and is easily understood, but it does well to satisfy the reflection of why it all happened the way it did, and could inspire another playthrough with that newfound understanding. Also helped by three different endings to witness if you're willing. There may be the unanswered question or two if you get to thinking about the details too long, but I didn't feel myself frustrated by that, as I always had an imagined one myself to put in place of those holes I found, and gratified that I had the option to do so when my ideas worked. 

I've had this game on my radar for years, always giving it another glance when I saw it on sale for cheap, but felt I knew what to expect and understood that it ended quickly so I left it lying, and much to my regret; this game is equal parts satisfying slash simulator as it is thought provoking and artistically delivered. The play time is my biggest quandary with this one, if money isn't an issue I think that this game is worth the asking price of $20 (at the time of this review,) but as someone who doesn't always have it to throw atcha' consoles and knows the consumer's condition it may be better to wait for the sale even if the devs deserve a little more for it. 

[spoiler] "A prison within a prison. A very clever trick." - The Voice [/spoiler]

I THINK, I recommend, but its close. There's only challenge here - nothing else to keep you going. You gotta love that and be in the game for that. The game is tough and you will curse. But its also elegant and rewarding and I have nice memories from it.

EDIT, after playing tons more hours (mostly offline): To my big surprise, I came back to this game years after finishing it for the first time and I got super hooked again. It is a rare instance of a game being good/tight enough to validate you REALLY engaging with it. There are a lot of small optimizations that allow you to be just a LITTLE bit more aggressive and take just a LITTLE bit less hits. Mastering all of this turned out to be a huge fun. I should mention that after all this, I have so far concentrated on speedrunnning Furi-difficulty but not even beaten Furier-difficulty, yet.
The point of this edit is - this game turned out to have huge replay value for me, offering both a massive quality and quantity of gametime. If you think you might find fun in really studying a game like this and mastering its mechanics, then I revise my "BARELY-recommended" to a wholehearted one!
Game devs - I salute you for an excellent game!

Looking for an isometric shooter that involves dodging projectiles? Looking for a game that involves close, one-on-one melee combat? Looking for a game with cutscenes that will make you feel like you're in an anime? Play Furi, because that pretty much sums up the game.

Furi's gameplay is fun and has the right amount of difficulty to make things interesting as you progress through each boss fight. On top of all of that, there's a cool story that keeps things interesting. The character design is on point, especially since Takashi Okazaki (the creator of Afro Samurai) was the character designer. I played this game on console and earned all of the achievements before I bought it on PC, and I can safely say that playing with a controller makes a lot more sense. Play Furi, it's a great game.

La verdad me faltan palabras para describir la tremenda joya oculta que es este juego y en cierto modo me apena que no haya tenido su digno reconocimiento. Descrito lo anterior, solo debo decir que para los "trophy hunters" es una experiencia única que deberían probar, a más de ser digno de pertenecer al abanico de juegos "platinados".

En conclusión, música de 10, gameplay dinámico al estilo "bullet hell" y una música que mejora la experiencia ampliamente.

101992064.review:
A unique taste... but not necessarily good.

I had been excited to try this game but kept forgetting about it. I decided to try it out and had read some very mixed reviews about it but player hype gave me the impression stuff was exaggerated on all accounts, especially with the very positive score. Thus I finally tried it out and... I was completely disappointed.

The art is good, if not for some caveats with the quality of some of the art. The music is acceptable. The rest is... very mixed to bad. In fact, it was so outrageously bad, with some caveats, that I actually did not get far into the game before quitting and writing this review and I will try to be unbiased in my presentation because in most circumstances a very incomplete review can be unreliable and often biased.

The dialogue, and what I was seeing of the story, is bad. In fact, it is so bad it almost warrants being illegal and its own meme for bad, and then furi bad. Surely I'm exaggerating right? YouTube it if you don't believe me. Even worse, the game's boss fights are split up in such a way that you are forced to deal with it as only a few tiny segments can be skipped while the rest you must hunch back old man style slow walk as the awful dialogue spews out, with the horrible camera angles, and uneventful snorefest commencing.

Then you have the combat... This could absolutely change later on so keep a reserved opinion about it but from what I've tried the game is not at all "difficult" and, in fact, calling it difficult because of actual designed difficulty would be an insult to the concept of difficult games. Keep in mind this is on the default Furi (normal) difficulty because, for some reason, the game locks Furier out until you beat this bland game at least once. Counters and boss patterns are incredibly forgiving. In fact, 90% of the combat is just knowing the boss patterns (which explains why they supposedly change it up some on Furier to give new patterns and why it seems the consensus is that, from what I've read, furier isn't much harder just new patterns...).

The game throws out some artificial difficulty by things like... The patterns change and the boss will simply enter an invulnerable (yellow) state and then jump off screen and then moments later teleport on top of you in a cutscene style pounce animation where she then hits you for multiple hits to your health bar. There is no visual cue playing out after she vanishes. This isn't clever design. You simply are almost guaranteed to eat the hit and then you have to "guess" and "test" at a possible risk of being hit again, or dying, and guess correctly with half random timing. Ta-da! You found out if you wait an estimated 0.5s and press dodge you dodge the ability! You likely took damage during this process at some point learning this pattern! This is just poor design. Fortunately, at least in Furi difficulty the game is very lenient on health, even ignoring the ability to heal in right conditions, and it even heals you up after beating a phase of the boss (one of its life bars, I think you have some as well under your own it looks like but never confirmed). Still this is not good design and if it happened during the end of a life you would simply die to it and along with other stuff it can add up. The physics detection is very bad with dash which causes another artificial difficulty increase. I don't have an issue with the delay like some, nor am I making a mistake and getting hit by bad dashing. The dash, in fact, is definitely taking hits at times when you've cleanly dodged and it is very visible because your body isn't anywhere near it especially if you record and slow down and watch the non-existent contact. In addition, it should grant invincibility frames during the dash but it definitely does not to certain attacks which can, I found in testing, consistently hit you even with very long range dashes vastly overstepping their collision area but the game tells you otherwise and there is no way to know what can be dashed and what cannot without trial and error similar to the prior complaint, free dmg potentially being built up and thus purely about patterns and information of quirks... The parry, at least on Furi, is cool and very forgiving with a noticeable delay and white glow when it is something that can be parried but, again, a boss might have a phase where it does 3 hits and then suddenly it will do 3 plus a very fast 4th hit in its pattern. This isn't a pattern mix-up but simply it shifts to the 4 hit pattern and exclusively uses it from then on but nothing visibly obvious like a phase shift leads into this change so it is... once again a really odd free source of dmg from the boss.

There are other sources of frustration with the mechanics that just make it less fun and more ideal to play in safer manners. The Strike charge is rarely worth the effort in normal movement phases, and often in restricted still feels like a gross waste (especially since normal attack combos are so effective there anyways) due to the boss often breaking it with a teleport or gaining instant invulnerability because it is pissed you took the effort to make this strike charge and found an opening to land it on them. The AI, quite literally, cheats to avoid it making it often not very effective in my testing compared to normal combos. There are odd cases in the melee restricted phase of the fight where the enemy uses its 4 hit combo pattern but then will stop after 1-2 hits randomly like it had an actual brain freeze and just stand there which is extremely jarring and lets you get free hits on it, though it often then breaks out of your combo (which is also jarring) in anywhere from 1-4 hits (even if you land all 4 hits for dmg it often will not take the mechanic knock down that is stated to apply and simply teleport...).

The first boss was easy enough, but the second boss was really bizarre. Due to its art design I initially thought it was a random turret type mob and not a boss and was very confused until I confirmed its health bar and then it changed patterns after losing its first life. It was excessively weak until its final life at which point it was still absurdly weak but some of the physics collision issues with dash came into play which was a bit annoying but not a big deal. The fight felt very wasteful. I also noticed a significant issue with the melee in the game which is that it randomly whiffs the air which caused some phases to take a tad longer than should. It seems like it typically tries to somewhat intelligently melee at the boss when you are near but there are times it forcibly melees at an odd angle going past them and no matter how you try it can take several random angle whiffs before it starts going back on the boss. This was very bizarre and outright annoying.

The final phase of the boss is just you dodging until its pattern ends (you aren't allowed to hit it due to permanent invulnerability) and then after its pattern is survived you hit it once for a cutscene and win which is very anti-climatic tbh. It is basically the game's final rush attempt to make you auto lose with a large scale frenzy spam of insane attacks, that are more intimidating than bite. This occurred on each boss I tried and was lackluster finale.

The game isn't something I'm going to say is outright terrible, but it isn't something I can readily recommend to others, either. I would prefer a neutral rating than a no but Steam does not allow this and I do not feel it warrants a yes without being informed for the average consumer.

What I came in expected was a boss rush type of experience with a it of dialogue in between. What I got was excruciatingly horrible between battle cutscenes/story and slow walking that took way the heck longer than I was okay with (and I love Metal Gear Solid and Xenosaga scenes, but at least they aren't awful) and then battles that were often very bland, well overstaying their welcome as they have like 12 phases

101586803.review:
I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy the game.

And I'd be the worst liar for saying I wouldn't even think of spending the game for an additional thousand hours. 

My honest recommendation: Buy it. This game was made by people who actually cares about their product and community, and even after 5 (five) whole years it still holds up to be one of, if not the best indie game out there.

First and foremost. Its gameplay. Unlike any other fancy stuff you see out there, it's plain simple. And that's the best part - YOU do your fancy shit with the game's relatively simple gameplay. And it's satisfying to beat the goddamn hell out of your enemy. And speaking of them - you only fight bosses. How many are there? I won't spoil. But for each and every single one of them, excluding DLC, will give you a complete workout, and it's a lots of fun. And it's pretty clear that they weren't just normal everyday bosses you fight, each of them has their own uniqueness, and combine that with speedrunning, will requires the best of your skill to defeat all of them within the designated time limit you set for speedrunning. This game has a built-in speedrunning mode, so you can become a real Furi professional™™™™ player, and flex on your poor friends who thinks they can get away with everything by holding a single button or spamming a single button for several thousand times.

For story, oh yeah this game has a story, albeit it's told through another person, not you. You are not the narrator. The game is your narrator so you can focus on the world around you, the inhabitants, to figure out what the hell happened. It's simple, but very enjoyable. And if you can't figure out the story... eh I think you can still do fine. The main focus is on characters, gameplay, and music afterall. 

Speaking of music, did you know that this game has a walking section, for both narration purpose, and for taking a break from beating the crap out of the bosses? Normally I'd be discarding every single forced walking section ever created by man, but holy shit, they know how to make it. They're made to make the atmosphere changes depends on the next boss you will encounter, and combine that with the narration, it truly one of the best part in the game despite being a forced walking segment. The game's short, hey, so give it a break.



Finally we talk about other stuff like graphics and controls. Graphics is of course, alright, during that time. But the way they make lighting, environment, makes it looks more beautiful than normal. And they literally showed it off right at the beginning of the game, the first boss. Controls are fine, of course relatively simple as the gameplay goes, and I've beaten the game on mouse/keyboard just fine. Controllers are ok, but I prefer mouse/keyboard and I had no problem with it besides the cancerous keybind for the charge shot.


Overall, BUY THE GAME. How the hell can you NOT buy the game after a bunch of words I spitted out for you to inspect? The game is AWESOME. GO. BUY. IT.

101041674.review:
This game is really is like a test for manoeuvre capabilities on gamepads. Some sections of the game really push the limits when it comes to tight-space manoeuvring; requiring you to dash through multiple projectiles and even parry some of them.

With that being said, I loved it. Yes, it's frustrating at times but the game doesn't punish you too harshly and really, aside from combat there isn't a single thing you can do in this game, so gitting gud is extremely satisfying since you can feel your skills getting better in every minute of the game.

The only complaint might be about how they managed some of the difficulty spikes between some phases of a couple of the bosses but I'm okay with that since every fight feels different and requires you to be equally focused. 
My last praise for the gameplay will be about controls, they are extremely snappy, responsive and accurate. Considering how much trouble would a single miscalculation or bad design about controls cause, this game frankly has no issues on that part.

Well, without a solid purpose none of those elements would matter, and I think this is a good point to mention the story. In Furi, we're basically fighting our way out from prison with a bunny-masked man guiding us. I don't want to spoil anything but I found the story powerful in a way that cause me to wonder about my character and our guide as I progress.
The presentation is also very Shadow of the Colossus, since the game consists only of boss fights, our character basically just walks from one boss to another and these walks are really a beauty to look at with gorgeous synth music in the background. 

This game has a distinct "character" which I think is the most important thing about an art piece, especially considering that we live in an age where hundreds of 'stuff' getting published every day. Standing out as a memorable experience is getting harder each day but I think Furi is a very memorable and beautiful experience that everyone should give a try.

side note: Character designs are made by Takashi Okazaki. What do you want more? 
side note2: the OST has singles from Carpenter Brut, Waveshaper, Danger... Again, what do you want more go play it already ( ͡ᵔ ͜ʖ ͡ᵔ )

[i] The jailer is the key, kill him and you’ll be free. [/i]

Furi was a game I had put off playing for a while but had heard great things about. Once I finally sat down and played it, I was pleasantly surprised. The game is essentially a boss rush with a walking simulator in between fights. 

The boss fights themselves are incredible, each having its own twist on the formula to help keep you on your toes. The gameplay is a mix between bullet hell and close quarters combat. The structure of each fight along with the health regen helps make the fight feel like it has rounds to it. 

The story is cryptic and will be drip fed to you in between each fight. Its mysterious nature helped keep me invested in it and made me want to finish each fight just to find out more. It also has multiple endings which I found to be a nice treat.

The music, besides the gameplay, is one of the best things about this game. Each track ebbs and flows with the fight to really get you pumped up.

My only real complaint is that there isn't a fight with a certain major character in the game, but I can see why there isn't for story purposes. The game is kind of short and really can be finished in under 10 hours, so I would recommend getting it on sale if you can. What started out as a mild interest became a fun and enjoyable ride for me, if you like indie games with fun combat and music, then Furi is the one for you.

98846009.review:
Furi is, gameplay-wise, not a bad game. I would call it, with some exceptions (like the dodge mechanic, the weird counter timing or the seemingly malevolent fixed camera), rather good overall. The melee combat, while certainly not close to the best I've seen, feels quite satisfying and the twin-stick shooter sections are pretty much exactly what you'd expect. Unfortunately, Furi also does what I think is the worst thing a game can possibly do - it wastes your time. If you don't mind that - and that's a big "if" - I'd say give it a try, but I'm about to go into why I don't think this game really deserves it.

Furi is structured as a series of duels with a number of bosses. Each boss is divided into multiple stages which usually alternate between bullet hell sections and melee fights (the later duels have far less focus on melee combat, sometimes dropping it almost entirely). Between the fights, you walk [i]very[/i] slowly through what amounts to unskippable cutscenes as the narrator bombards you with what little story the game has to offer (curiously, there are also real cutscenes that [i]are[/i] skippable). And here is the game's real problem: [u]you only get checkpoints between fights[/u]. In other words, if you die at any point throughout a fight, be prepared to replay up to, say, about 15 minutes of gameplay. And since this is a game mostly about pattern memorisation (which is to be expected from a melee/bullet hell hybrid) with unforgiving difficulty (in later fights, some enemy attacks are literal one-hit-kills), unless you are a true expert at this kind of gameplay already, you [i]are[/i] going to be replaying huge chunks of Furi. Get ready to see the same animations, hear the same handful of voicelines, repeat the same patterns of attacks potentially dozens of times.

In essence, I think Furi would be a perfectly worthwhile game if it didn't have its difficulty artificially skyrocketed by an unreasonable distribution of checkpoints. I do think, however, that it is quite easy to guess why this decision was made - [u]there is very little game in this game[/u]. A walkthrough on YouTube puts Furi's real length at about 2 hours - and that's [i]including[/i] all the long sections where nothing happens and you can just press a key to have the game play itself. So I think it's not unreasonable to assume that rather than being a legitimate gameplay-driven decision, the cruel save system was implemented to pad the game's laughable playtime as much as possible. And don't think Furi plays fair, either - the final sections of most boss fights seem specifically designed to kill you unless you've already played them and things like being respawned in the middle of an enemy attack or having to hide behind off-screen cover that might not even be there at the time are not uncommon. The earlier fights also use QTEs that are both extremely tedious and sometimes seemingly random in their outcome.

And while this is relatively unimportant, I'd also like to point out that on a technical level, Furi is rather subpar. While the overall look of the game may be appealing depending on personal preferences, I found it very distracting how models perpetually clip through themselves and everything is bathed in a terrible blurry haze that cannot be disabled, as far as I can tell. The game is also incredibly adamant that you should play it with a gamepad, but that's actually not that much of an issue - in case you do want to play it with a keyboard and mouse (which may very well be preferable for the shooting mechanics), the only problem you'll face is that you can only move in 8 directions due to the fixed camera, so the dodging will feel even more awkward.

In summary, Furi would be a fine - perhaps even genuinely good - game in my eyes if it didn't go out of its way, more than any other game I have ever played, to waste my time. If you're the type of person who enjoys playing the same thing over and over again, you may very well enjoy your time with Furi as well - but despite having completed several difficult games (including ones that do require countless repeated attempts, llike TrackMania titles), I gave up on Furi towards the end, since I came to the conclusion that this game simply doesn't have anything in it to justify putting so much effort into beating it, especially when it seems so determined to waste as much of my time as possible. One last thing I should mention is that there is, in fact, an easy mode - which I admittedly haven't tried - designed to let players experience the story without the fights presenting a challenge. However, I am absolutely convinced that the game's 2-hour-long story, which I found to be rather unengaging and delivered in a remarkably mundane manner, does not justify purchasing Furi just to experience its narrative.
