97826666.review:
A furious, action-packed hell of a game that will keep you full of adrenaline for every minute of the battles, Furi is living proof that a game doesn't have to be long to be good. To elaborate on what the game has to offer:

[*] An eye-catching, neon aesthetic that oozes sci-fi vibes despite being relatively minimalistic.
[*] The soundtrack, courtesy of several very talented artists who worked together to bring an insanely good score that oozes with futuristic energy. It really has to be heard to be believed, but it's both incredibly memorable and always evocative of the challenge the game is currently throwing at you.
[*] Since the boss fights are basically the only thing in the game, they had to go all-out for them - and they delivered. Each fight is stunningly well done, full of character matching your opponent, and strikes a very thin line between very difficult and very fair. The bosses have loads of health and relentless attacks which seamlessly integrate both bullet-hell and close-quarters combat, but rarely punish you to such an extent that making mistakes is fatal, as long as you can learn from them - omnipresent telegraphs and predictable attack patterns help with this. In addition, the fights are pretty generous - not only do you get multiple lives per fight (which only restart you at the start of the phase unless you lose all 3, and recover one life every time you beat a phase), you can parry or shoot down most bullets, and you can also heal by parrying melee blows or shooting down certain attacks.
[*] On that topic, the combat system is insanely satisfying. The combination of ranged shoot-em-up bullet hell segments, fast-paced melee combat, and an extremely agile character is masterfully done (especially with your combat tools, which can be exploited to ridiculous degrees if you take the time to learn them), and the game makes it very clear early on that this isn't a game where you can spam everything to death. You can punish a boss' openings just as easily as they can punish you if you get too overzealous, making for combat that manages to be frantic yet calculated, lightning-fast yet methodical.
[*] Each boss has their own unique design and distinct personalities, and considering how little you see of each of them, the amount of characterization the game gives you for each is impressive.
[*] The story is very short and very open-ended, but still more than meaningful enough for one to stay invested, which is pretty impressive considering it's almost all exposition.

It does, however, admittedly have a few shortcomings:

[*] Dodge and parry timing in this game is a little unintuitive, as in dashing happens after you release the button instead of when you tap it, and parrying has a noticeable delay. While I got used to it pretty easily, it can take some time and trouble getting used to it, especially if you've played other games without said quirks. The fact that I played the game on keyboard instead of the recommended controller might have had something to do with it.
[*] For some reason, the walking segments in between battles - basically glorified cutscenes - can't be skipped. They're very memorable the first time you do them, but can prove to be infuriatingly long on repeat runs. To add insult to injury, the regular cutscenes are skippable.

All in all, though, this is a must-play for players who want a sci-fi, adrenaline-riddled combat gauntlet with a side of good game design and absolutely banging music.

However, I definitely recommend changing the dash (L1) in Steam Config to "start press" to remove the obnoxious delay in the dash. Then unbind L2 long-press/analog, and bind L2 soft-press to L1. Furi is a game I definitely slept on for way too long. After going back to it years after I first bought it, I was treated to some of the most satisfying parry-heavy and high-paced combat that a game can offer, sandwiched between amazing world design and masterfully done narration.

Reminiscent of games such as No More Heroes, each boss oozes with personality and are all brutal but fair as you learn their patterns and quirks. Each and every time, getting the last hit on a boss that seemed to be nearly impossible to manage at first was immensely satisfying, and every winning run through a boss felt like a seamless flow of attack and defense that was just as fun to watch as it was to play.

Obviously, I can't talk about this game without bringing up the absolutely stunning soundtrack. While walking to each boss, you are treated to ambient tracks that slowly ramp up as you get closer and closer, building up amazing suspense. The actual combat themes shift as you go from phase to phase and are absolutely perfect at capturing the feel of each fight.

Bottom line, I would 100% recommend this game.

This game was on my to-be-finished list for years. I beat the main campaign in a day or two, but the One More Fight DLC expansion always held me back from finishing it. The secret final boss is insane compared to the rest of the game. Every now and then I would pick the game up again, only to be unable to make it even a quarter of the way through its health bar. One More Fight is what separates the casual from the truly skilled. In the end, it took me 5 and a half hours to beat the boss. I used the in-game commands to practice it one stage at a time, and after my training was concluded and I took a stab at the real thing, I beat the final boss on my first try. My sense of pride and accomplishment has never been greater.

Also, Benjamin Le Moullec, Furi's combat designer, is an absolute god at this game. I salute you, Mr Le Moullec.

97318937.review: One of the most underrated games of the 2010s and a true gem that should be remembered for all time. A game that relies on nothing but pure skill is a rare thing in this era of standard collapse, and the devs should be commended for creating a trial of a game.

97235723.review:
Furi will forever be one of my absolute favorite games, ever. And I'm saying this as someone who really doesn't care about boss rush modes. So this is really saying something. Furi is a game made by people who love games as much as they understand game design. Absolutely every aspect of this game works perfectly in tandem with the others. The gameplay is condensed, tight, very intense — but you always feel in control. It might be tough, but it's never unfair. You always have a chance, and the rush you get from prevailing through challenges is incredible. The artstyle is creative, unique, interesting and was not created alongside the game, but FOR it. The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal and even after years of playing, I still listen to it and get all excited, as if I was in the middle of the game. And finally, the story and narrative are strong and wonderfully used to pace the game and keep you curious, while never intruding on your fun. 

The game hooks both your intrinsic and extrinsic motivation and takes you on a wild ride. If you even remotely think that Furi might be for you: Buy it. Buy it, right now. You'll love it.
